questions.text:
On performing polysomnography in a patient, the waves of EOG, EEG, and EMG, from above downwards, are seen below. Which stage of sleep do the marked areas represent?


	EOG: Electrooculography
	EEG: Electroencephalography
	EMG: Electromyography

choices.text:
NREM II sleep

NREM III sleep

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) REM sleep

Explanation:

  • Based on the provided features of EOG, EEG, and EMG, the correct stage of sleep is REM sleep.

 

REM findings on EEG, EOG, EMG

 

EEG (Electroencephalogram)

• EEG activity is increased similar to the awake state (beta activity) along with the return of alpha activity

• The typical appearance of these waves is known as Sawtooth waves or Sawtooth appearance.

• Paradoxical sleep: Even though the person is sleeping, the EEG shows activity similar to that of the awake state.

• PGO (Ponto Geniculo Occipital) spikes are also seen - Large phasic potentials that originate from Pons (the cholinergic neurons) and go towards the lateral geniculate body and to the occipital spikes.

EOG (Electrooculogram)

Rapid eye movements are seen

EMG (Electromyogram)

• Tonic atonia (as if the muscle is in paralysis) with phasic twitches

• It means there is a near-complete loss of muscle tone, preventing movement during vivid dreaming.

 

 

NREM sleep: This is divided into 3 stages

  • Stage 1: N1 stage
  • Stage 2: N2 stage
  • Stage 3 and Stage 4: Stages 3 and 4 have been combined into one stage known as the N3 stage.

 

Stage

EEG

EOG

EMG

Awake (Stage W)

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) with eyes closed

Eye movements and blinks present

High tonic activity, voluntary movements

N1 Stage (Light Sleep) (Option B)

Loss of alpha waves, theta waves (4-7 Hz)

Slow eye movements

Tonic activity decreases

N2 Stage (Moderate Sleep)

(Option C)

Sleep spindles (12-14 Hz), K complexes (sharp negative followed by positive waves)

None

Very low tonic activity

N3 Stage (Deep Sleep)

(Option D)

Delta waves (slow, high amplitude)

None

Low tonic activity

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			
				Kleptomania
			
			
			
			
				Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
			
			
		
		
			
			2. Pyromania
			
			
			B. Intense desire to mutilate
			
		
		
			
			3. Mutilomania
			
			
			C. Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
			
		
		
			
			4. Dipsomania
			
			
			D. Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Explanation:

 

Kleptomania
  • It is the intense desire to steal items of trivial value
  • It is managed by insight-oriented psychotherapy, psychoanalysis, CBT, and behavioural therapies (e.g., systematic desensitization).
  • Medications: SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants, lithium, naltrexone.

Pyromania
  • It is the intense desire to burn things
  • Treatment is challenging; CBT is the most promising approach,and family therapy is essential for youth.
  • Limited medication options; potential benefits from SSRIs, lithium, and naltrexone.

Mutilomania

It is the intense desire to mutilate

Dipsomania

It is the intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. She is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females
In adults, equally among males and females

In adults, it occurs more in males than in females

In children, it occurs more in females than in males
In children, it occurs more in females than in males

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) In children, it occurs more in females than in males

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests conversion disorder and its prevalence is more common in females than males, particularly in children and adolescents.
  • Conversion disorder is where there is a neurological symptom (like blindness) that cannot be explained by any organic pathology and is often associated with psychological stress or conflict (in this case, the recent loss of the patient’s mother).
  • La Belle Indifférence is a term used to describe a striking lack of concern or emotional distress about physical symptoms or disabilities, typically seen in patients with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion Disorder (Functional neurological disorder)

  • Predominantly, the symptoms of conversion disorder are neurological and are paradoxically experienced as involuntary or lacking in self-agencies.
  • Seen in Females > males (Option A, B and C ruled out)
  • Onset- Late childhood to early adulthood.
  • Presentation of conversion disorder:
    • Presents with symptoms suggestive of deficit in motor or sensory functions or both.
    • But without any evidence of any physical disorder.
    • Reason- Too much stress has converted the stress into these neurological symptoms.
    • At times, the symptoms are inconsistent with the anatomy and physiology of the body. E.g. inconsistent tremors.

 

Symptoms of Conversion Disorder

Sensory symptoms

Motor symptoms
  • Paresthesia
  • Anesthesia
  • Deafness
  • Blindness
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Abnormal movement
  • Paralysis, paresis
  • Gait disturbances
  • Astasia-abasia gait
  • Pseudo seizures

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics causes hypertension?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Cocaine

 

Explanation:

  • Cocaine: It causes hypertension by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine at adrenergic nerve terminals, leading to increased sympathetic activity, vasoconstriction, and elevated blood pressure.
  • Cocaine is unique among local anesthetics due to its sympathomimetic effects, which can lead to hypertension and tachycardia.

Lignocaine (Lidocaine) (Option B): It primarily acts as a sodium channel blocker and does not cause significant effects on blood pressure unless given in large doses or if it contains epinephrine.

Bupivacaine (Option C): Known for its cardiotoxicity at higher doses, but it does not typically cause hypertension.

Prilocaine (Option D): Generally safe for local use, with minimal systemic effects on blood pressure.

questions.text:
Arrange the following agents on the basis of their potency.


	Nitrous Oxide
	Halothane
	Isoflurane
	Methoxyflurane

choices.text:
Methoxyflurane > Nitrous Oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane

Methoxyflurane > Nitrous Oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous Oxide

 

Explanation:

The potency of inhalational anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). A lower MAC value indicates higher potency because less anesthetic is required to achieve anesthesia.

  1. Methoxyflurane: The most potent inhalational anesthetic with the lowest MAC value.
  2. Halothane: More potent than isoflurane but less potent than methoxyflurane.
  3. Isoflurane: Has a higher MAC than halothane, indicating lower potency.
  4. Nitrous Oxide: Has the highest MAC (over 100%), making it the least potent anesthetic.

Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) is a measure used to compare the potency of inhalational anesthetic agents. It is defined as:

The alveolar concentration of an anesthetic at 1 atmosphere of pressure that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standard surgical stimulus, such as a skin incision.

Key Points about MAC:

  1. Inverse Relationship with Potency:
    • Lower MAC = Higher potency (less anesthetic needed to achieve the desired effect).
    • Higher MAC = Lower potency (more anesthetic required).
  2. Factors Affecting MAC:
    • Age: MAC decreases with age.
    • Body temperature: Hypothermia reduces MAC.
    • Concurrent medications: Drugs like opioids and benzodiazepines decrease MAC.
    • Physiological state: Pregnancy and certain conditions (e.g., hypoxia, hypotension) lower MAC.
    • Alcohol: Acute alcohol intake reduces MAC, while chronic use increases it.
  3. Clinical Use:
    • MAC is used to determine the dosing of inhalational anesthetics.
    • For surgical anesthesia, a concentration higher than MAC (e.g., 1.2–1.5 MAC) is typically used to ensure immobility in nearly all patients.
  4. MAC Values for Common Agents (Approximate):
    • Nitrous Oxide: >100% (very low potency)
    • Methoxyflurane: 0.16% (extremely high potency)
    • Halothane: 0.75%
    • Isoflurane: 1.15%

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child visits with symptoms of fever, joint pain, and a visible skin abnormality on his hand, as depicted in the provided image. Please identify the clinical observation and suggest a probable diagnosis.

choices.text:
Sclerodactyly-Systemic sclerosis

Mechanic’s hand – Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Gottron’s papules – Juvenile dermatomyositis

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows erythematous, scaly plaques over the knuckles (MCP and PIP joints), which are characteristic of Gottron’s papules.
  • Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM) is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting children.
  • Associated features include proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and systemic symptoms like fever and arthritis.
  • Diagnosis is based on clinical findings, muscle enzymes (CK), EMG, and muscle biopsy.

Juvenile Dermatomyositis:

Feature

Description

Skin findings

Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly plaques on knuckles), heliotrope rash (violaceous eyelid discoloration)

Muscle involvement

Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair)

Systemic symptoms

Fever, arthritis, fatigue

Investigations

Elevated CK, aldolase, anti-Jo-1 antibodies, EMG, muscle biopsy

Treatment

Corticosteroids, methotrexate, IVIG in severe cases

 

Rheumatoid nodules – Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are firm, non-tender subcutaneous nodules over pressure points (e.g., elbows, fingers) in juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). These nodules are not scaly or violaceous and do not appear over joint extensor surfaces like Gottron’s papules.

 

Sclerodactyly – Systemic sclerosis (Option C) is incorrect because sclerodactyly refers to thickened, tight skin over the fingers due to dermal fibrosis, seen in systemic sclerosis (scleroderma). It is not associated with Gottron’s papules or muscle weakness.

 

Mechanic’s hand – Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D) is incorrect because mechanic’s hands (hyperkeratotic, cracked palmar skin) are seen in antisynthetase syndrome, often associated with dermatomyositis and polymyositis, but not systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a pregnant woman who is 12 weeks pregnant and undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy but is now experiencing type 2 lepra reaction?

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids

Thalidomide

Continue MDT and add oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Continue MDT and add oral steroids

 

Explanation:

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is an immune complex-mediated reaction seen in multibacillary leprosy. Pregnancy does not alter the management of leprosy itself, and stopping multidrug therapy (MDT) is not recommended. The preferred treatment for type 2 reactions includes oral corticosteroids, which are safe in pregnancy. Thalidomide is strictly contraindicated due to teratogenicity.

Leprosy and Its Management in Pregnancy

Aspect

Details

Cause of Leprosy

Mycobacterium leprae

Types of Reactions

Type 1 (Reversal), Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Type 2 Lepra Reaction

Immune complex-mediated (Type III hypersensitivity)

Common Symptoms

Painful nodules, fever, malaise, neuritis

Management of Type 2 Reaction

Corticosteroids (safe in pregnancy)

Role of MDT in Pregnancy

Must be continued to prevent relapse

Drugs to Avoid

Thalidomide (teratogenic)

 

Management of Type 2 Lepra Reaction in Pregnancy

Aspect

Details

Continue MDT

Essential to prevent disease relapse

Preferred drug

Oral steroids (prednisolone)

Avoid in pregnancy

Thalidomide (teratogenic, causes phocomelia)

Supportive therapy

Analgesics, wound care if ulcerated lesions present

Alternative options

Clofazimine has mild immunomodulatory effects

 

Stop MDT and start oral steroids (Option A) is incorrect because stopping MDT can lead to disease relapse and worsening nerve damage. MDT must be continued while managing the reaction with steroids.

 

Antibiotics (Option B) is incorrect because type 2 lepra reaction is an inflammatory immune response, not an infectious complication. Antibiotics have no role in managing ENL itself.

 

Thalidomide (Option C) is incorrect because thalidomide is highly teratogenic (causing phocomelia and limb defects) and is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. Although thalidomide is an effective treatment for ENL, it should never be used in pregnant women.

questions.text:
Please match the following types of scales with their corresponding lesions.

 


	
		
			
			Scales
			
			
			Lesions
			
		
		
			
			1. Collarette scales
			
			
			a. Pityriasis versicolour
			
		
		
			
			2. Silvery scales
			
			
			b.Pityriasis rosea
			
		
		
			
			3. Mica–like scales
			
			
			c.Psoriasis
			
		
		
			
			4. Branny scales
			
			
			d.Pityriasis lichenoides
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Each type of scale is associated with a characteristic dermatological condition:

  1. Collarette scales – Pityriasis rosea (1-b)
    • Fine, trailing collarette of scales surrounding oval, salmon-coloured plaques seen in pityriasis rosea.
    • Most prominent around the edges of herald patches.
  2. Silvery scales – Psoriasis (2-c)
    • Thick, silvery-white scales over erythematous plaques, classically seen in psoriasis.
    • Removal may lead to Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding).
  3. Mica-like scales – Pityriasis lichenoides (3-d)
    • Fine, adherent mica-like scales covering small, erythematous papules.
    • Seen in pityriasis lichenoides, a chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  4. Branny scales – Pityriasis versicolour (4-a)
    • Fine, powdery, branny scales seen in pityriasis versicolour, a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia.
    • Often reveals yellow-green fluorescence under Wood’s lamp.

Scales in Dermatology:

Scales are abnormal accumulations of keratinized cells on the skin surface and are characteristic of various dermatological conditions. They can vary in thickness, texture, and pattern based on the underlying disease.

Type of Scale

Description

Associated Disease

Key Clinical Features

Collarette scales

Thin, peripheral scales arranged in a collarette pattern, often seen in annular lesions.

Pityriasis rosea

Herald patch followed by a "Christmas tree" distribution of lesions.

Silvery scales

Thick, silvery-white, adherent scales that bleed upon removal (Auspitz sign).

Psoriasis

Well-demarcated erythematous plaques on extensor surfaces, scalp, and lower back.

Mica-like scales

Fine, thin, shiny scales resembling mica.

Pityriasis lichenoides

Chronic or recurrent papulosquamous eruptions.

Branny scales

Fine, powdery, furfuraceous (bran-like) scaling.

Pityriasis versicolor

Hypo- or hyperpigmented macules caused by Malassezia, commonly on the trunk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with hypopigmented patches on the skin. On examination, there are a few well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions with a loss of sensation. Skin smears reveal no acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Paucibacillary leprosy

 

Explanation:

  • Hypopigmented patches with sensory loss strongly suggest leprosy rather than other dermatological conditions.
  • Well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions are characteristic of paucibacillary leprosy, which presents with five or fewer skin lesions with nerve involvement.
  • Skin smears revealing no acid-fast bacilli indicate a low bacterial load, confirming paucibacillary leprosy rather than multibacillary leprosy.

Leprosy:

Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, primarily affecting the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. It presents in a spectrum based on bacterial load and immune response.

Classification of Leprosy (Ridley-Jopling & WHO Classification)

Type

Immune Response

Skin Lesions

Nerve Involvement

AFB Smear

WHO Classification

Tuberculoid (TT)

Strong (Th1)

Few, well-defined, anesthetic

Single nerve thickening

Negative

Paucibacillary (PB)

Borderline Tuberculoid (BT)

Moderate

Multiple, asymmetric, anesthetic

Multiple nerves affected

Variable

Paucibacillary (PB)

Borderline Borderline (BB)

Unstable

Numerous, irregular plaques

Moderate nerve involvement

Positive

Multibacillary (MB)

Borderline Lepromatous (BL)

Weak (Th2)

Diffuse, infiltrative lesions

Severe nerve damage

Strongly Positive

Multibacillary (MB)

Lepromatous (LL)

Absent

Diffuse, nodular, leonine facies

Symmetric nerve thickening

Strongly Positive

Multibacillary (MB)

 

Clinical Features of Leprosy

System Involved

Clinical Features

Skin

Hypopigmented or erythematous macules, plaques, nodules, loss of sweating (anhidrosis)

Nerves

Thickened peripheral nerves, sensory loss (glove and stocking pattern)

Eyes

Lagophthalmos, keratitis, blindness

Musculoskeletal

Claw hand, foot drop, joint deformities

Systemic

Testicular atrophy, gynecomastia (LL type)

 

Diagnosis of Leprosy

Diagnostic Method

Findings

Clinical Diagnosis

Hypopigmented/anesthetic skin lesions, nerve thickening

Skin Smear (Ziehl-Neelsen Stain)

AFB seen in multibacillary leprosy but not in paucibacillary leprosy

Lepromin Test

Positive in tuberculoid leprosy, negative in lepromatous leprosy

Skin Biopsy

Granulomas in tuberculoid leprosy, foam cells in lepromatous leprosy

Nerve Biopsy

Shows caseation necrosis in tuberculoid type

 

Treatment of Leprosy (WHO Multidrug Therapy – MDT)

Type

First-Line Treatment (Duration)

Paucibacillary (PB)

Rifampicin + Dapsone (6 months)

Multibacillary (MB)

Rifampicin + Dapsone + Clofazimine (12 months)
  • Pregnancy & lactation: MDT is safe.
  • Children: Treated with adjusted doses based on weight.

Leprosy Reactions & Management

Reaction Type

Features

Treatment

Type 1 (Reversal)

Inflammatory response in existing lesions, nerve damage

Steroids (Prednisolone)

Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL)

Painful nodules, fever, neuritis, systemic involvement

Steroids, Clofazimine, avoid Thalidomide in pregnancy

Lucio Phenomenon

Ulcerative necrotizing lesions

Rifampicin, Clofazimine

 

Prevention & Public Health Measures

  • BCG vaccine offers partial protection.
  • Early diagnosis & MDT prevents transmission.
  • Household contacts should be screened regularly.
  • Reconstructive surgery for deformities in chronic cases.

 

Multibacillary leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because MB leprosy presents with multiple lesions, often widespread, with no sensory impairment in early stages and a positive skin smear for Mycobacterium leprae (acid-fast bacilli). This patient’s negative smear and limited lesion count favour paucibacillary leprosy.

 

Psoriasis (Option B) is incorrect because psoriatic plaques are erythematous with silvery scales, not hypopigmented. Sensory loss is not a feature of psoriasis, and skin smears do not play a role in its diagnosis.

 

Tinea versicolor (Option C) is incorrect because pityriasis (tinea) versicolor, caused by Malassezia spp., presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules, but there is no sensory loss. The lesions are typically scaly, and a KOH mount would reveal spaghetti and meatballs appearance (yeast and hyphae).

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to mother’s milk in a low birth weight (LBW) baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Human donor milk

 

Explanation: Human donor milk is the best alternative to mother’s milk in a low birth weight (LBW) baby.

 

Choice of Milk in LBW:

  • All low birth weight (LBW) infants should receive only breast milk, regardless of their initial feeding method.
  • Feeding methods: Paladai or gastric tube can be used for feeding.
  • Source of breast milk: Expressed breast milk can be either the mother's own milk or human donor milk.

 

Donor milk is preferred over preterm formula as it reduces the risk of necrotising enterocolitis, offers comparable long-term growth and neurodevelopmental outcomes, provides non-nutrient benefits like improved immunity, and serves as a safer alternative when maternal milk is unavailable.

 

Special Situations:

Sick Mothers or Contraindication to Breastfeeding:

  1. Temporary Alternatives: When a mother is sick or breastfeeding is contraindicated, the following options are available:
    • Formula Feeds:
      • Preterm formula for very low birth weight (VLBW) infants. (Option B)
      • Term formula for infants weighing >1500 g at birth. (Option C)
    • Animal Milk: Cow’s milk (lacking vitamin C, iron, and essential fatty acids, and containing high levels of protein and lactose that can cause digestive and allergic issues in infants) can be used as an alternative. (Option A)
  2. Resumption of Breastfeeding: Once the mother’s condition stabilizes or the contraindication resolves, exclusive breastfeeding should be initiated for these infants.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Explanation: The closest calculated eGFR in the patient is 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA.

 

Schwartz formula

 

GFR (mL/min/1.73 m²) = (k x height (cm)) / Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

 

  • Substituting the values:

GFR = (0.41 x 100 cm) / 1 mg/dL = 41 mL/min/1.73 m² BSA.

 

  • Purpose: Quick, bedside estimation of GFR using serum creatinine and height.
  • Creatinine-Based: The formula uses serum creatinine as a marker, which can be affected by factors such as age, muscle mass, and diet.
  • Height Inclusion: Height is included in the formula to account for the relationship between body size and kidney function, which is particularly important in growing children.
  • Constant "k": The value of k varies as a function of age and sex being 0.33 in preterm infants, 0.45 in full-term infants, 0.55 in children and adolescent girls, and 0.70 in adolescent boys.
  • This formula is generally used for estimating GFR in children and adolescents up to 18 years old.
  • Limitations:
    • Accuracy issues in populations with altered creatinine production or excretion.
    • Not a gold standard; less accurate compared to inulin or iohexol clearance.
  • Clinical use:
    • Often used alongside other findings to assess kidney function.
    • Interpret results within the broader clinical picture, recognizing limitations.


 

Age Group

GFR (mL/min/1.73 m²)

Inference

Birth (Full-term Infants)

15-20

GFR is low at birth; renal function is still maturing.

Birth (Preterm Infants)

10-15

Lower GFR compared to full-term infants due to underdeveloped kidneys.

2 Weeks

35-45

Rapid increase in GFR as renal function starts maturing.

2 Months

75-80

Continued rapid increase, nearing levels seen in older infants.

Childhood (up to 2 years)

Approaches 80-120 (comparable to adults after correction for body size)

Renal function continues to improve, reaching near-adult GFR levels by age two when corrected for body surface area.

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true?


	Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
	Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
	Cotrimoxazole is not given.
	Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2, 4 

 

Explanation: The true statements regarding urinary tract infections (UTI) in children are that bowel-bladder dysfunction increases the risk of UTI recurrence, and micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is performed in cases of recurrence.

 

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs) in Children: 

  • Etiology and Prevalence:
    • Primary Cause: Colonic bacteria ascending the urinary tract.
    • Common Pathogen: Escherichia coli (54-67% of cases). (1)
    • Other Pathogens: Klebsiella spp., Proteus spp., Enterococcus, Pseudomonas.
  • Clinical Features and Classification:
    • Pyelonephritis (Kidney Infection): Upper renal collecting system involved
      • Symptoms: Abdominal/back/flank pain, fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
      • Newborns: Non-specific symptoms like poor feeding, irritability, jaundice, weight loss.
    • Cystitis (Bladder Infection): Only bladder involved
      • Symptoms: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain, incontinence, malodorous urine.
      • Typically does not cause high fever or renal injury.
  • Risk Factors for Recurrent UTI:
    • Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)
    • Bladder-Bowel Dysfunction (BBD) (2)
    • Obstructive Uropathy
    • Urinary Tract Abnormalities: Anatomical issues like labial adhesion.
    • Neuropathic Bladder
    • Catheterisation: Procedures introducing bacteria.
    • Sexual Activity: Increases UTI risk in females.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Urine Culture: Gold standard for UTI diagnosis; identifies and quantifies bacteria.
      • Interpretation: 
      • A colony count of >50,000 colony-forming units/mL of a single pathogen, along with pyuria or bacteriuria in a symptomatic child, is generally considered diagnostic of a UTI.
    • Urinalysis: Leukocyte Esterase and Nitrites positive.
    • Imaging Studies: 

Treatment:

  • Antibiotic Therapy: Mainstay of UTI treatment.

Treatment Specific to UTI Presentations

 

Acute Cystitis

• Common Antibiotics: TMP-SMX (cotrimoxazole) (3), Nitrofurantoin, Amoxicillin 

• Duration: 3-5 days

Acute Pyelonephritis

• Hospitalized: IV Ceftriaxone, Cefepime, Cefotaxime

• Outpatient: Oral Cefixime, Cephalexin

• Avoid Nitrofurantoin, use Fluoroquinolones for resistant strains.

• Duration: 7-14 days

Acute Lobar Nephronia/Abscess

• Similar to pyelonephritis, but longer duration (14-21 days)

• Percutaneous or surgical drainage for abscesses

questions.text:
A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do?


	Chest X-ray
	Oxygen administration
	Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes
	Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation: In acute asthma exacerbation, oxygen administration, salbutamol nebulization, and oral corticosteroids are essential to stabilize the patient, while a chest X-ray is not routinely needed unless alternative diagnoses or complications are suspected.

 

Management of Acute Asthma attacks

Immediate Treatment
  • Oxygen Therapy (2): Administer via mask or nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 92%.
  • Inhaled SABAs (3):
    • Albuterol: 2.5 mg/3 mL nebulized every 20 mins for 3 doses;
    • Levalbuterol: 1.25 mg/0.5 mL up to 3 doses every 20 mins.
  • Systemic Corticosteroids (4):
    • Prednisone: 1-2 mg/kg/day orally (max 60 mg/day);
    • Methylprednisolone: 1-2 mg/kg IV, then oral dosing.

Adjunctive Treatments
  • Inhaled Anticholinergics, Ipratropium Bromide: 0.5 mg nebulized every 6-8 hours as needed.
  • Intravenous Magnesium Sulfate: 25-75 mg/kg IV over 20 minutes (max 2 grams).

Escalation of Care
  • Continuous Nebulization:
    • Albuterol: 10-15 mg/hour via nebulizer.
  • Parenteral β-Agonists:
    • Terbutaline: 2-10 µg/kg IV loading dose followed by 0.1-0.4 microgram/kg/min titrate in 0.1-0.2 µg/kg/min increments every 30 min
    • Epinephrine: 0.01 mg/kg SC or IM, repeat every 15-30 min if needed.

Monitoring & Management
  • Close Monitoring:
    • Continuous monitoring of vital signs, oxygen saturation, and clinical response. Assess improvement in symptoms, PEF, and lung function.
  • Risk Assessment for Discharge:
    • Criteria: Sustained improvement, PEF > 70% predicted, oxygen saturation > 92% on room air. Ensure home capability for medication administration.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures?


	Age <1 year
	Temperature of 38-39°C
	Duration of fever <24 h
	Duration of fever >48 h
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation: The risk of recurrence of febrile seizures is increased in children aged <1 year, with a temperature of 38-39°C, and a fever duration of less than 24 hours.

 

Criteria for Diagnosis of Simple Febrile Seizure:

  • Age: 6-60 months (peak incidence at 12-18 months).
  • Fever: Associated with a temperature ≥38°C (100.4°F).
  • Seizure Characteristics: Generalized, usually tonic-clonic.
  • Duration: Seizure lasts ≤15 minutes.
  • Recurrence: No recurrence within 24 hours.
  • Postictal State: Rapid return to baseline consciousness without neurological deficit.
  • Exclusion of Other Causes: No signs of CNS infection, metabolic imbalance, or history of afebrile seizures.

 

Risk Factors for Recurrence of Febrile Seizure:

Major Risk Factors
  • Age <1 yr (1)
  • Duration of fever < 24 hr (3)
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F) (2)

Minor Risk Factors
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Lower serum sodium at time of presentation

 

Types of Febrile Seizures:

Simple Febrile Seizure

Complex Febrile Seizure
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seizure.
  • Lasts ≤15 minutes.
  • No recurrence within 24 hours.
  • Quick recovery to baseline without deficit.
  • Lasts >15 minutes.
  • It may be focal in nature.
  • It may recur within 24 hours.

Common between 6-60 months, benign, and does not require extensive workup.

Higher risk of recurrence, and it requires further evaluation.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Liver iron concentration

 

Explanation: Liver iron concentration is the best method to detect iron overload in thalassemia patients undergoing multiple blood transfusions.

 

Iron Overload in Thalassemia:

  • Iron Overload Mechanisms in Thalassemia:
    • TDT (Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia):
      • Regular blood transfusions lead to iron accumulation (0.3-0.6 mg/kg per day).
      • Iron is released into plasma after transfused red blood cells are phagocytized and binds to transferrin.
      • Once transferrin is saturated, non-transferrin-bound iron enters organs like the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
      • Iron accumulation causes organ damage via reactive oxygen species.
    • NTDT (Non-Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia):
      • Increased intestinal iron absorption due to hepcidin suppression and ineffective erythropoiesis.
      • Iron primarily accumulates in the liver, not the myocardium, unlike in TDT.
         
  • Diagnosis and Quantification of Iron Overload:
    • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
  • MRI with R2 or T2 technique is the gold standard for quantifying liver iron concentration (LIC) and cardiac iron in thalassemia.
  • Iron Overload Thresholds:
    • LIC in NTDT: Values >5 mg/g correlate with increased morbidity.
    • LIC in TDT:
      • 7 mg/g dw indicates increased risk of complications.
      • 15 mg/g dw is predictive of advanced liver fibrosis and increased cardiac risk.
  • Cardiac T2 MRI: (Option B)
    • <10 ms predicts higher risk of heart failure and mortality.
    • 10-20 ms is linked to reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and arrhythmias.
    • However there can be discrepancy between liver iron and cardiac iron levels.
  • Serum Ferritin Assessment: (Option C)
    • Used as a screening tool.
    • Ferritin levels correlate with hepatic iron overload in both TDT and NTDT.
    • However, it is not as accurate for detecting iron overload in thalassemia patients, as ferritin levels can be elevated due to other factors (e.g., inflammation).
  • Non-Transferrin-Bound Iron (NTBI): (Option D)
    • Refers to iron that is not bound to transferrin, typically occurring in iron overload conditions when iron exceeds the binding capacity of transferrin.
    • NTBI is a labile form of iron that can contribute to iron toxicity.
    • While NTBI can serve as an indicator of iron overload, it is influenced by plasma factors like citrate, uric acid, and albumin.
       
  • Management of Iron Overload in Thalassemia:
    • Iron Chelation Therapy (ICT):
  • Aims to manage iron stores, reduce iron in tissues, and reverse heart failure.
  • Three main chelators used: Deferoxamine (DFO), Deferiprone (DFP), and Deferasirox (DFX).
  • TDT: Start ICT after 10 transfusions or by age 2 years.
  • NTDT: Begin assessment at age 10, with consideration for MRI-based evaluation of organ-specific iron load from age 8-10 years.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the non-contrast CT scan of a patient given below:
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Hydatid cyst

 

Explanation:

A calcified cyst on a non-contrast CT scan is characteristic of a hydatid cyst caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The calcification indicates a chronic or resolved infection, typical in the late stage of a hydatid cyst. Hydatid cyst is caused by infection with Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis.

 

The disease progresses through stages: cyst formation, growth, and eventual calcification. On a non-contrast CT scan, calcified hydatid cysts appear as well-defined, round or oval lesions with peripheral or complete calcification. This calcification signifies a chronic or inactive cyst.

 

The cyst's "water lily sign" or "daughter cysts" (when present) are specific features but are better visualised on other imaging modalities.

In endemic areas, calcified hydatid cysts are diagnostic of previous or resolved hydatid disease.

 

WHO Classification of Hydatid Cysts (Cystic Echinococcosis):

The WHO classification is based on ultrasound findings, helping in diagnosing and managing cystic echinococcosis.

WHO Classification

Ultrasound:

  • Primary modality for evaluating hydatid cysts.
  • Identifies key features like floating membranes and daughter cysts.

 

CT and MRI: Used for detecting complications (e.g., cyst rupture, infection).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) CT Limbs

 

Explanation:

Whole-body CT protocols for trauma patients are designed to assess life-threatening injuries quickly. They focus on critical areas such as the head, cervical spine, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. CT scans of the limbs are not routinely included unless there is specific clinical suspicion of significant limb injuries.

 

CT Head (option A): This is included to detect traumatic brain injuries, fractures, or haemorrhages, which are common in major trauma cases.

 

CT Cervical spine (option B): This is included to evaluate for cervical spine fractures or ligamentous injuries, which are critical in trauma patients with suspected spinal injuries.

 

CT Abdomen (option D): This is included to identify abdominal organ injuries, bleeding, or free fluid, which are crucial to diagnose promptly in trauma management.

questions.text: When do fingerprints first develop during intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
• By 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life, the basic pattern of fingerprints is formed.
  • These patterns are unique to each individual and remain unchanged throughout life.

 

Key points about dactylography and fingerprints:

  1. Dactylography, also known as dactyloscopy, is the study of fingerprints as a method of identification.
  2. There are four basic fingerprint patterns: loop, whorl, arch, and composite.
  3. Fingerprints remain constant throughout embryonic life, birth, and life of the individual.
  4. An individual's genetic makeup plays a part in determining the basic shapes of the patterns and ridges, but it is not the only factor.
  5. Fingerprints can be erased permanently and deliberately by criminals to reduce their chance of conviction, through various methods including burns, acids, and plastic surgery.

 

Permanent impairment of fingerprint patterns

Leprosy, electric injury, and after exposure to radiation.

Ridge atrophy with alteration of ridge pattern

Celiac disease, dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis, acanthosis nigricans,

scleroderma, and dry and atrophic skin.

Loss of fingerprints

Anti-cancer drug- capecitabine

Elderly persons

Fingerprints that are difficult to capture, since the elasticity of skin decreases with age

No fingerprints

Genetic disorders like Baird syndrome

(congenital milia), Zinsser-Cole-Engman syndrome (dyskeratosis

congenita),Naegeli-Franceschetti-Jadasohn syndrome,dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis, and adermatoglyphia

 

  1. Quetlet’s Rule- Every natural form presents infinite variations and no patterns are ever alike. Dactylography is based on this rule.
  2. Dactylography is crucial for forensic experts and law enforcement professionals in their investigative work, including criminal identification, disaster victim identification, and various legal procedures

Pattern Type

Frequency (%)

Loop (Ulnar/radial)

60-70

Whorl

30-35

Arch

5-10

Composite

1-5

questions.text: Identify the given plant based on its features
questions.solution:
The above image matches the characteristics of Argemone Mexicana, known for its yellow flowers and toxic properties.

 

  • Argemone Mexicana:
    • Commonly known as prickly poppy.
    • The plant is characterized by its yellow flowers, prickly leaves, and a milky sap.
    • It is toxic due to alkaloids such as sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine, which can cause health issues like epidemic dropsy.

 

Argemone Mexicana (Prickly Poppy)

Toxic Parts

Entire plant; seeds resemble mustard seeds but are darker with minute projections.

Toxic Oil

Argemone oil (katkar oil) causes epidemic dropsy.

Active Principles

Plant Alkaloids: Berberine, Protopine.

Oil Alkaloids: Sanguinarine, Dihydrosanguinarine. (Cause abnormal blood vessel permeability.)

General Symptoms

Gradual onset with appetite loss, diarrhea, leg edema, and generalized anasarca.

System-Specific Signs

Heart: Myocardial damage, heart dilatation.

CVS: Hypotension, breathlessness, feeble pulse.

Hepatic: Enlarged, tender liver.

PNS: Tingling, hyperesthesia, calf muscle tenderness, reduced or absent jerks.

Ocular: Dim vision due to increased intraocular pressure.

Skin: Bluish mottling from peripheral vessel dilation.

Fatal Outcome

Severe heart damage.

Treatment

Balanced diet, decontamination, cessation of oil consumption, diuretics, corticosteroids, and supportive care.

Medico-Legal Aspects

Argemone oil is commonly used to adulterate mustard or other edible oils.


 

Datura Alba (Option A): Known as white datura, it has white trumpet-shaped flowers and is associated with anticholinergic toxicity.

Nerium Odorum (Option C): Known as oleander, it has pink or white flowers and contains cardiac glycosides causing poisoning.

Papaver Somniferum (Option D): Commonly known as the opium poppy, it produces latex rich in alkaloids like morphine and codeine.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination reveals specific findings. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
he presence of small, superficial cuts suggests a possible moment of doubt or fear before inflicting the fatal injury. These small cuts can be indicative of hesitation, often observed in scenarios of self-infliction or in cases where the victim may have struggled before the lethal wound.

 

Hesitation cuts:

  • Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin.
  • These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound.
  • Psychological Aspect: They suggest that the individual may have hesitated while gathering the courage to make a decisive cut.
  • Forensic Observation: In cases of homicidal sharp force injuries, multiple superficial, roughly parallel incised wounds may appear on the neck, often adjacent to a single deep, lethal incised wound, particularly in instances where torture is involved.


 

Grazed abrasion (Option B):

  • Superficial injury caused by a tangential force, resulting in skin being scraped off.
  • Commonly occurs during falls or friction injuries.

 

Laceration (Option C):

  • Irregular tear in the skin caused by blunt force trauma, often accompanied by tissue bridging.

 

Patterned bruise (Option D):

  • Bruises that replicate the shape of the causative object (e.g., belt marks or shoe prints).
  • Seen in cases of physical assault or trauma.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning?
questions.solution:
The primary treatment for acute arsenic poisoning is dimercaprol, a chelating agent that binds arsenic and facilitates its excretion.

 

Management of Arsenic Poisoning

 

Supportive treatment

Gastric lavage, airway, breathing, and circulation management (intravenous fluids, cardiac monitoring, etc.).

Medical treatment

Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote)

Chelating agents
  • BAL (Dimercaprol)
  • DMSA (Dimercapto succinic acid) or DMPS (Dimercapto propane sulfonic acid)
  • Penicillamine

Other measures
  • Purgatives like Castor oil or Magnesium sulfate (remove unabsorbed poison from the intestine).
  • Glucose-saline with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis or exchange transfusion.

 

Ipecac (Option A): Previously used to induce vomiting but is no longer recommended due to the risk of aspiration and limited efficacy.

Penicillamine (Option B): Another chelating agent, primarily used for copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson’s disease). Less effective than dimercaprol in arsenic toxicity.

Activated charcoal (Option C): Used for gastrointestinal decontamination in various poisonings. Not effective in chelating or removing absorbed arsenic.

questions.text: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropa belladonna, also known as "Deadly Nightshade," contains tropane alkaloids (atropine, scopolamine). While it affects the autonomic nervous system (causing tachycardia, dry mouth, and dilated pupils), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison.

 

Some common cardiac poisons include:

  • Aconite (Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox)
  • Nicotine (Nicotiana tabacum)
  • Digitalis (Digitalis purpurea)
  • Oleander (Cerbera thevetia, Cerbera odorum)
  • Quinine.

 

Aconite (Option A):

  • Aconite is cardiac poison derived from the Aconitum plant.
  • It causes arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest by altering sodium channel function.

Cerbera thevetia (Option B): Commonly known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that interfere with the sodium-potassium ATPase pump.

 

Nicotiana tabacum (Option C): Tobacco contains nicotine, which can act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and cause tachycardia or bradycardia depending on the dose.

questions.text: What is this finding suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Antemortem Drowning features include the presence of froth in the mouth and nostrils, water in the lungs, hyperinflated lungs, and diatoms in internal organs.These findings indicate that the individual was alive at the time of submersion and inhaled water, leading to drowning.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs: Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged, Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Drowning after organophosphate poisoning (Option A):
Incorrect because organophosphates may cause respiratory depression or paralysis, but they do not cause typical signs like frothy fluid due to struggle during drowning.

Drowning after arsenic poisoning (Option C):
Incorrect because arsenic causes gastrointestinal symptoms and circulatory collapse but does not produce the classic drowning features like froth or emphysema aquosum.

None of the above (Option D):
Incorrect because antemortem drowning is the correct diagnosis based on classic forensic findings.

questions.text: What is the function of the superior oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
The superior oblique muscle, innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV), is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. Dysfunction of this muscle causes vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking down, such as when walking downstairs.

questions.text: Which of the listed conditions is associated with the presence of punched-out lesions on the retina?
questions.solution:
• The most probable diagnosis in this scenario is toxoplasmosis uveitis, which is caused by Toxoplasma gondii
  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii and is a common cause of posterior uveitis. It can lead to punched-out lesions in the retina, which are characteristic of the disease. These lesions typically appear as well-defined, round areas of retinal scarring.
  • Fundoscopy shows focal necrotizing retinitis surrounded by a distinctive “headlight in the fog” appearance
  • An immunocompromised person living with cats is a risk factor for toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis uveitis:

  • It is a protozoan infestation.
  • Organism: Toxoplasma gondii
  • Definitive host - cats
  • Intermediate hosts - humans
  • Systemic lesions are more common in immunocompromised patients

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Most common cause of posterior uveitis and focal necrotizing retinitis (90% of cases)
  • Congenital
    • Inactive disease - Healed punched out heavily pigmented chorioretinal scars in the macular area

 

 

  • In active inflammation - “headlight in the fog” appearance due to intense vitritis
  • Acquired
    • Asymptomatic
    • Same as congenital
    • Punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis

 

Treatment:

  • Quadruple therapy: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Clindamycin + Oral steroid
  • Steroid eye drops for anterior uveitis

 

Posterior staphyloma (Option A): This refers to an outpouching of the sclera in the posterior part of the eye, often seen in high myopia (nearsightedness). It typically does not cause punched-out lesions on the retina.

 

Fundal coloboma (Option B): A coloboma is a congenital defect that can affect various parts of the eye, including the retina. It usually results in a hole or defect in the eye structure but does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Congenital Rubella (Option C): Rubella can cause retinal changes in infants born with the infection, but it is more associated with "salt-and-pepper" retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

questions.text:
Which structures are affected in a pregnant woman who exhibits fever, retroorbital pain, headache, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, and tinnitus, while having normal blood pressure and fundus?

1. Abducens nerve

2. Oculomotor nerve

3. Internal carotid artery

4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in this pregnant woman, such as fever, retroorbital pain, headache, pulsatile proptosis, and tinnitus, suggest a possible case of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

  • Abducens nerve: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) runs through the cavernous sinus. It is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Compression or dysfunction can cause pulsatile proptosis and eye movement abnormalities.
  • Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) also passes through the cavernous sinus and controls most of the eye's movements, including the muscles responsible for pupil constriction. Dysfunction here can lead to ptosis and pupil abnormalities.
  • Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery runs through the cavernous sinus and can be affected in cases of sinus thrombosis or vascular pathology. Pulsatile proptosis and tinnitus are often signs of vascular involvement (e.g., arteriovenous fistula or carotid-cavernous fistula).
  • Cavernous sinus: The cavernous sinus is a critical structure that houses several cranial nerves (III, IV, V1, V2, and VI) and the internal carotid artery. Thrombosis or infection here can lead to a constellation of symptoms involving nerve dysfunction and vascular compromise.
  • Given the symptoms and the structures involved, the correct answer is Option D: A, B, C, D, since all these structures (abducens nerve, oculomotor nerve, internal carotid artery, and cavernous sinus) are likely affected in this scenario.

Cavernous sinus Thrombosis:

  • Typically results from infections such as sinusitis, orbital cellulitis, or otitis.
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe headache
    • Malaise
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Unilateral or bilateral proptosis
    • Chemosis
    • Congestion of facial, conjunctival, and retinal veins
    • Reduced vision
    • Cranial nerve dysfunction (third to sixth cranial nerves)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging, especially MRI and MRI venography
    • Systemic infection investigations, including lumbar puncture
  • Treatment:
    • Intravenous antibiotics
    • Possible surgical drainage
  • Prognosis: High mortality rate (20% with treatment, up to 100% untreated)

Options A, B, & C are incorrect.

questions.text: During a routine eye examination, a patient's visual acuity was evaluated using Snellen's chart, and it was determined to be 6/6. What is the smallest angle at which this patient can differentiate two separate points or objects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer-  (Option B)

Explanation

  • Visual acuity of 6/6 means the patient has normal visual acuity, which is the ability to see clearly at a distance of 6 meters what should normally be seen at that distance.
  • The smallest angle at which the eye can differentiate two points is referred to as the angular resolution of the eye. For a person with normal vision (6/6), this is approximately 1 minute of arc per line on the Snellen chart.
  • However, the smallest angular separation that the human eye can typically distinguish under optimal conditions is 5 minutes of arc. This corresponds to the smallest angle at which a person with normal vision can resolve two separate points as distinct.
  • Normal visual acuity (6/6) corresponds to a subtended angle of 5 minutes of arc.

 

Snellen’s chart
  • Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points.
  • Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc.
 

Visual Acuity Notation
  • Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters).
  • Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision.
  • Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity.

Testing Procedure

The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter.

Limitations
  • Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses.
  • Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability.
  • Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision.

 

15 minutes of arc (Option A): This is too large an angle for normal visual acuity. It corresponds to a less sharp visual resolution.

 

10 minutes of arc (Option C): This is also larger than the typical 5 minutes of arc resolution of normal vision.

 

20 minutes of arc (Option D): This is even larger and would correspond to a more impaired level of visual acuity.

questions.text: After an acute episode of angle-closure glaucoma, which triad of symptoms is typically observed?
questions.solution:
• Vogt's triad is a clinical set of findings typically associated with acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) after an attack has been resolved.
  • The triad helps in identifying damage caused during the acute episode.

 

Features of APAC:

  • Descemet membrane folds
  • Iris atrophy
  • Irregular pupil
  • Glaucomflecken
  • Cataract
  • Cupping +/-

 

Vogt’s triad:

It may be seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute PAC. It is characterized by:

  1. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil (due to sphincter atrophy)
  2. Glaucomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity)
  3. Patches of iris atrophy

Virchow's triad (Option B): This refers to the three factors that predispose to thrombosis: stasis of blood flow, vascular injury, and hypercoagulability. It is used in the context of venous thrombosis, not glaucoma.

 

Hutchinson's triad (Option C): This refers to a set of findings associated with congenital syphilis, including notched incisors, interstitial keratitis, and sensorineural hearing loss.


Gaucher's triad (Option D): This refers to symptoms seen in Gaucher's disease, a genetic disorder involving lipid storage. The triad includes hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and anemia, unrelated to glaucoma.

questions.text:
Which cranial nerves does the oculocephalic reflex evaluate?

A. III

B. IV

C. VI

D. VIII

E. VII
questions.solution:
The oculocephalic reflex (doll's eyes reflex) evaluates the following cranial nerves:

  • III (Oculomotor nerve): Controls most of the eye’s movements, including the medial rectus (for adduction of the eye).
  • VI (Abducens nerve): Controls the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for moving the eye laterally.
  • VIII (Vestibulocochlear nerve): Involved in the vestibular system, which helps detect head movement and contributes to the reflex response.

Thus, the correct answer is Option D: A, C, and D.

Oculocephalic Reflex (Doll's Eyes Reflex)

  • Assesses the vestibular-ocular reflex (VOR) to evaluate cranial nerves 3, 6, and 8, brainstem function, and overall neurologic status. It is commonly used in neurologic critical care, for neonates, anesthetized patients, and those with dizziness.
  • Procedure: The examiner holds the patient’s eyelids open and rotates their head from side to side.
    • Positive reflex: Eyes move in the opposite direction of head rotation, indicating intact brainstem function.
    • Negative reflex: Eyes stay midline, indicating possible severe brainstem dysfunction.
    • A similar test can be performed for vertical eye movements.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Vestibular Lesions: Lesions to the vestibular system can impair the reflex.
    • Dizziness: Abnormal responses indicate possible vestibular dysfunction.
    • Psychiatric Patients: Schizophrenia and bipolar patients show abnormal smooth pursuit eye movements but typically maintain an intact doll's eyes reflex.
    • Intensive Care: The reflex can predict altered mental status (delirium, coma) after sedation cessation.
    • Neonates: The reflex is active in neonates before 11.5 weeks and serves as a developmental milestone.
    • Anesthesia & Ophthalmologic Surgery: The reflex is useful for assessing brainstem function in these contexts.
  • Caution: Do not perform on patients with head or neck injuries that could worsen from the reflex technique.

questions.text:
What would be the next investigative step for a 27-year-old female patient who presents with sudden vision loss accompanied by a relative afferent pupillary defect in her right eye, while her left eye appears normal on examination?

1. MRI brain & orbit

2. Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies

3. Blood sugar

4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
The sudden decrease in vision and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) suggests a pathology with the optic nerve in the right eye, most likely due to optic neuritis, which can be associated with demyelinating diseases like Multiple sclerosis (MS) or Neuromyelitis optica (Devic's disease).

 

  • MRI scan of the brain and orbit should preferably be performed in each case presenting with acute optic neuritis to check for nerve swelling, optic nerve glioma, cerebral, and brainstem lesion.
  • MOG and NMO antibodies: These antibodies are seen in autoimmune conditions affecting the central nervous system, like Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica (NMO). Detection of these antibodies can help confirm the diagnosis.
  • Blood sugar levels have to be checked. Because Optic neuritis is Primarily treated with Steroids as Steroids may precipitate hyperglycemia in individuals with DM.
  • A thyroid profile could be relevant in cases of thyroid eye disease, but this typically presents different symptoms, such as eye protrusion, redness, and double vision. Given the scenario, thyroid dysfunction is less likely.
  • Thus Option A: 1, 2 and 3 is the correct answer

 

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dilated esophagus with a "bird beak" appearance, suggesting Achalasia Cardia, where 24-hour pH monitoring is unnecessary as the condition primarily involves structural and motility issues, not acid reflux.

 

Achalasia Cardia

Definition

Progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the oesophagal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry (Option C ruled out)

  • Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the oesophagus.
  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram) (Option A ruled out)

  • Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy (Option B ruled out)

  • Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris; it is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

Management

Pharmacological Treatments

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (reduce LES pressure)
  • Nitrates (relax the LES)
  • 5'-Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors (increase cyclic GMP to lower LES pressure)
  • Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections (temporarily paralyse LES muscles).

Non-Surgical Interventions

  • Bougie/Balloon Dilatation (ruptures LES muscle fibres to reduce pressure).

Surgical Treatments

  • Laparoscopic Heller's Cardiomyotomy (Most common)
    • The incision in the LES muscle to reduce pressure.
    • It is often combined with a fundoplication.
  • Partial Fundoplication
    • Prevents reflux; options include Dor or Toupet fundoplication.
  • Esophagectomy
    • Surgical removal of the esophagus (severe cases).

Endoscopic Treatments

  • Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM): A newer Minimally invasive procedure involving dissection of LES muscle fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following causes maximum malnutrition?
questions.solution:
• Duodenal Fistulas can cause maximum malnutrition, as the duodenum is crucial for nutrient absorption, including proteins, fats, carbohydrates, vitamins, and minerals.
  • It occurs as a complication of:
    • Gastric resection
    • Duodenal resection
    • Biliary tract procedures
    • Pancreatic resections
    • Trauma
    • Perforated peptic ulcers
    • Cancer.
  • There is a direct connection between the duodenum and an abnormal opening, causing significant nutrient loss and malnutrition.

 

(A) The smaller duodenal fistula was repaired over a t-tube; (B) The larger fistula was closed with interrupted sutures. (C) Pyloric exclusion; (D) Jejuno-jejunostomy following segmental resection of jejunal fistula; (E) Feeding jejunostomy

 

Pancreatic fistula (Option A) leads to the loss of digestive enzymes, but the body can adapt to some extent, causing less severe malnutrition than a duodenal fistula, where nutrient absorption is directly impaired.

 

Distal ileal fistula (Option C) affects the absorption of bile salts and vitamin B12, but it doesn’t impact the absorption of a wide range of nutrients like the duodenum, which is responsible for absorbing most nutrients from digested food.


Colonic fistula (Option D) mainly affects water and electrolyte absorption, leading to dehydration or imbalances, but it has less impact on overall nutrient absorption compared to a duodenal fistula, which disrupts early nutrient uptake.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves would be involved if a patient experiences a loss of sensations over the root of the penis after undergoing open hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
• The loss of sensation at the root of the penis after open hernia surgery likely involves the Ilioinguinal Nerve.
  • It originates from the first lumbar nerve and passes through the inguinal canal.
  • Supplies: Sensory innervation to the upper medial thigh, the root of the penis, and mons pubis in males.
  • During open hernia surgery, this nerve can be damaged or irritated, resulting in a loss of sensation in the structures.

Hernia Surgery

  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve. (Option B)
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve.
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

 

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterization.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

 

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option A) provides sensory innervation to the lower abdomen and the upper part of the thigh, but it does not innervate the root of the penis. It is less likely to be involved in loss of sensation at the root of the penis.

 

Genitofemoral nerve (Option C) does provide sensation to the skin of the genital area; it mainly innervates the scrotum and labia, not specifically the root of the penis. It is less likely to be affected in this case.


Medial cutaneous nerve to the thigh (Option D) provides sensation to the inner thigh, but it has no direct involvement in the sensory innervation of the penis. Therefore, it wouldn't cause loss of sensation over the root of the penis after surgery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism presents to the hospital. A splenectomy is planned for this child. All the following vaccines are recommended before splenectomy except?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not recommended before Splenectomy, as Salmonella typhi is not an encapsulated organism and is not directly linked to the increased infection risk after the procedure.

Reason for vaccination:

  • Normal function of the spleen: Phagocytosis of encapsulated organisms.
  • Post-splenectomy septicemia is majorly due to encapsulated organisms S. pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides, Haemophilus influenzae, or Escherichia coli.

Vaccine recommendations for asplenic patients:

Vaccination

Children

Adults (age 19 and older)

Pneumococcal (Option A ruled out)

  • PCV13 followed by PVC13 8 weeks later.
  • PPSV23 8 weeks later.
  • Repeat PPSV23 at 5 years
  • PCV13 followed by PPSV23 8 weeks later
  • Repeat PPSV23 every 5 years

Meningococcal (Option D ruled out)

MenACWY series AND MenB series
  • MenACWY or MPSV4 2 months apart
  • Repeat MenACWY every 5 years AND MenB series once.

Haemophilus influenzae type B (Option C ruled out)

Hib once if 15 months or older and previously not vaccinated

Hib once
  • Time for vaccination:
    • Ideally- 10-12 weeks before surgery
    • At Least 2 weeks before an elective surgery
    • Emergency splenectomy- At discharge or 14 days after surgery, whichever is first.
  • CDC immunisation guidelines for 2020 also recommend tetanus (Tdap or Td), human papillomavirus (HPV), measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR), varicella, zoster, influenza, hepatitis A (hep A) and hepatitis B (hep B), and meningococcal vaccines.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about psoas abscess are true?


	Fluctuant swelling in the hip
	Cold abscess can develop from Pott’s abscess
	Pain on the passive extension of the hip joint is seen
	It develops more commonly through the hematogenous route in immunocompromised patients and elderly.
questions.solution:
All of the above statements regarding Psoas Abscess (also known as Retroperitoneal Abscess) are correct.

  • It is an abscess of the retroperitoneum.
  • Causes:
    • Tuberculosis (TB) of the spine (Pott’s disease). (Statement 2)
    • Secondary to direct spread of infection from the inflamed digestive or urinary tract (with or without perforation).
    • Advanced Crohn’s disease.
    • Haematogenous spread from an occult source (immunocompromised patients) (Statement 4)
    • Intravenous drug misuse.
  • Presentation:
    • A fluctuant swelling in the hip region with localised swelling and inflammation. (Statement 1)
    • Pain and discomfort in the hip area. (Statement 3)
  • Imaging:
    • X-ray: Intact right psoas muscle shadow, but the left psoas shadow is absent, with a large radiopacity in the left lumbar region.
    • CT Scan: A large bilobed, peripherally enhancing collection in the upper two-thirds of the left psoas muscle, extending into the left pararenal space, displacing the left kidney superiorly, with thickening of the lateroconal fascia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman was brought to the AIIMS emergency following a road traffic accident. She was hemodynamically stable, and her GCS score was 3. She was intubated and sent for non-contrast C,T which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this road traffic accident scenario with a low GCS score of 3 and a normal CT scan, the most likely diagnosis is Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI), which often appears normal on CT despite causing severe neurological damage.

 

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

A form of primary brain injury caused by widespread damage to axons due to rotational acceleration and deceleration forces, often associated with high-energy trauma.

Cause
  • Rotational forces: High-energy accidents involving rapid acceleration and deceleration (e.g., motor vehicle collisions).
  • Trauma: Blunt force impacts that cause the brain to rotate within the skull.

Clinical Features
  • Impaired arousal: Often presents as coma or reduced consciousness due to damage in critical brain areas (e.g., pontine reticular activating system, bilateral thalami).
  • Neurological deficits: Poor neurological examination despite the absence of obvious radiographic global brain injury.
  • Irreversible consequences: DAI is often associated with severe and lasting neurological impairment.

Investigations
  • CT scan: May show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem in severe cases.
  • MRI:
    • More sensitive than CT.
    • It shows small haemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury, particularly in patients who fail to improve neurologically.
  • Postmortem examination: Confirms the diagnosis with axonal disruption and formation of axon balls.

Prognosis

Very poor due to high risk of severe disability or death due to extensive brain damage.

 

Subdural hemorrhage (Option A) would usually cause a gradual decline in GCS, and a CT scan would typically show a crescent-shaped blood collection. The normal CT scan, in this case, makes subdural hemorrhage less likely.

Extradural haemorrhage (Option B) presents with a brief loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval, and a CT scan typically shows a convex-shaped blood collection. The normal CT, in this case, makes extradural hemorrhage unlikely.

Cerebral contusion (Option D) can result from trauma and may cause neurological deficits; they typically appear as focal areas of haemorrhage or swelling on a CT scan. A normal CT scan, as seen here, makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a pelvic fracture following blunt abdominal trauma. No blood is seen at the meatus. Catheterisation does not produce significant urine output. The radiological image is given below. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.solution:
The patient’s pelvic fracture, absence of blood at the meatus, and minimal urine output on catheterisation, along with radiological findings suggestive of Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture, indicate that immediate laparotomy is required.

 

Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture

Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males.

Causes

Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region.
  • Signs of shock and syncope.
  • Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis.
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Haematuria
  • Absence of desire to urinate

Diagnosis
  • Plain X-ray: It may show a ground glass appearance.
  • Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity.
  • Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualise bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops.
  • Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries.

Treatment
  • Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option C).
  • Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers.
  • Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity.
  • Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity.
  • Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
  • Catheterisation:
    • Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically.
    • Foley's catheter passed urethrally.

Complications
  • Cystitis /and pyelonephritis.
  • Peritonitis.
  • Pelvic abscess.
  • Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical).
  • Paralytic ileus.
  • Hemorrhage.

 

Suprapubic cystostomy (Option A) is used to divert urine in cases of bladder injuries, but it’s typically considered when there is a lower urinary tract injury, such as bladder rupture without peritoneal involvement.

 

Per Urethral catheterisation (Option B) is performed to assess for urethral injury or urinary retention. However, in cases of pelvic fractures with suspected bladder rupture (especially intraperitoneal), catheterisation may exacerbate the injury or is not helpful.


Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy (Option D) is typically used for severe hemorrhagic shock and pelvic fractures with significant bleeding, often in cases of pelvic vascular injuries.

questions.solution:
A fibroadenoma, with its characteristic appearance and benign nature, falls under BIRADS 2, representing benign findings on imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
• In Meckel's Diverticulum, the most frequently found ectopic tissues are gastric and pancreatic tissues.
  • Persistent remnant of the Vitello-intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct.

Meckel's Diverticulum

Clinical features
  • Most common ectopic mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum is Gastric > Pancreatic > Colonic (Option A) (Option B, C ruled out)
  • The most common symptom in children is gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Ulcers are formed in the surrounding area due to acid secreted from the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum, which causes bleeding.
  • The most common symptom in adults is abdominal pain.
  • Complications: Volvulus, intestinal obstruction, intussusceptions, diverticulitis and perforation.

Investigations
  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan: Absorbed by the ectopic gastric mucosa, allowing for visualisation.
  • Plain abdominal radiography, CT abdomen, and ultrasonography are seldom useful.
  • Endoscopy: Helpful in false-negative cases, but not the investigation of choice.

Management

  • Healthy base (no induration or ulceration): Diverculectomy (excision of the diverticulum only) + anastomosis.
  • Unhealthy base (ulceration, presence of gastric mucosa): Resection of the small bowel with the diverticulum + anastomosis.
  • Incidentally detected during an elective surgery: Diverculectomy.


Thyroid and lung (Option D) tissue are extremely rare in Meckel’s diverticulum. These tissues are not typically associated with diverticular formations in the small intestine.

questions.text: What is true about gall bladder carcinoma?

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Gallstones and gallbladder cancer are easily distinguished clinically
Median survival is less than 6 months

questions.solution:
Gallbladder Cancer is a deadly disease with a median survival of less than 6 months, a 5-year survival rate of 50% for localised cases (with chemotherapy), and 2-5% for those with distant metastasis.

 

Gallbladder Cancer

Etiology

  • Gallstones
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction
  • Cholesterosis of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps
  • Porcelain gallbladder
  • Infections and inflammatory conditions
    • Chronic typhoid carriers
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections
  • Other factors:
    • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
    • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
    • Nitrosamines
    • Carcinogens

Clinical features

  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases (Option C ruled out)
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage) (Option B ruled out)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage) (Option A ruled out)

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnostic Imaging
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging and Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Management
  • Early disease:
    • For disease confined to the mucosa, if there is negative cystic duct margin and no recurrence on imaging- No further treatment
  • For transmural disease- Radical en bloc resection of gallbladder fossa, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes.
  • Advanced Cancer:
    • Non-operative palliative care.
    • Endoscopic/percutaneous methods to relieve obstructive jaundice.
  • Adenocarcinoma:
    • Early-stage limited to mucosa:
  • No additional treatment is required if imaging shows no recurrence.
  • Beyond mucosa:
    • Extensive surgery involving gallbladder fossa, a portion of the liver, and nearby lymph nodes.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone appendectomy 2 days ago presents with severe abdominal pain. On exploration, there is a collection of blood in the abdomen. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during surgery?
questions.solution:
The appendicular artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery, supplies the appendix, and if not properly ligated during an Appendectomy, can lead to postoperative bleeding and blood collection in the abdomen.

 

Steps during Open Appendectomy:

Right colic artery (Option B) supplies the ascending colon, not the appendix. It is not typically involved in an appendectomy, so failure to ligate it would not cause bleeding related to the appendix.

Superior rectal artery (Option C) is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies the rectum. It has no role in the blood supply to the appendix, and failure to ligate it would not result in bleeding from an appendectomy.

Superior mesenteric artery (Option D) supplies the small intestine, cecum, and parts of the colon, but it does not directly supply the appendix. Ligating this artery would affect a broader region but is not specific to preventing bleeding during appendectomy.

questions.text:
What should be the subsequent step in managing a 32-year-old male patient who comes to the surgical emergency department with a 2-day history of peptic ulcer disease, experiencing abdominal pain, bloating, and difficulty passing stools?


	IV fluids
	CECT abdomen
	Exploratory laparotomy
	Upper GI endoscopy


Below is the provided X-ray film image
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, bloating, difficulty passing stools, and air under the diaphragm suggest intestinal perforation, requiring IV fluids for stabilisation and exploratory laparotomy for surgical intervention.

 

Complications of duodenal ulcer:

Duodenal ulcer perforation
  • Common with anterior duodenal ulcers.
  • Presents with an acute abdomen with sudden-onset, severe epigastric pain, rebound tenderness, and air under the diaphragm in the radiograph. (Option B)
  • Management:
    • Non-surgical:
      • Nil per-oral
      • IV antibiotics and PPIs
    • Surgical:
      • Initial empirical antibiotic treatment.
      • The perforation is approached by a small upper midline incision
      • Perforations <1cm are closed primarily and buttressed with a well-vascularized omentum
      • Larger perforations & with fibrotic edges: Modified Graham's Repair or Omental Patch Repair.
      • The vascularized pedicle of the greater omentum is patched over the defect.

Bleeding duodenal ulcer
  • A posterior duodenal ulcer is the one that usually bleeds.
