  • It is due to the involvement of the gastroduodenal artery.
  • This leads to hematemesis, melena or both i.e., an upper GI bleed.
  • Bleeding is commonly associated with intake of NSAIDs.
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic: Done to find the bleeding source and manage bleeds endoscopically. Injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue are the methods used. (with or without adrenaline injection).
    • Angiographic management: If endoscopic management fails.
    • Surgical management:
      • Exposure to the ulcer and ligation of the duodenum are the principles here.
      • Duodenotomy
      • Ligation of the bleeding vessel with truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty

Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO)
  • Acute inflammation of the duodenum or pylorus leads to mechanical obstruction with a functional gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Presents with nausea, early satiety, vomiting, loss of weight, and anorexia.

Hourglass deformity

It is seen in chronic gastric ulcers with scarring and fibrosis.

Pyloric stenosis

It is seen in cases of chronic ulcers, which lead to stricture and constriction of the pylorus.

 

CECT abdomen (Statement B) can help assess the extent of the perforation, but it is not the first step in this emergency scenario. The presence of air under the diaphragm on the X-ray already suggests perforation and surgical intervention is the priority.


Upper GI endoscopy (Statement D) can diagnose peptic ulcers in the case of a perforation, but an immediate exploratory laparotomy is needed to repair the hole and prevent further complications. Endoscopy is not suitable for this emergency.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement regarding gastric carcinoma:


	It is mostly hereditary
	E-cadherin adhesion defect is seen in diffuse types of gastric CA.
	Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA.
	Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis.
questions.solution:
B and C statements are correct regarding Gastric Carcinoma.

Category

Risk factors

Diet

High-salt foods (e.g., salted and smoked meats), low intake of fruits and vegetables

N-nitroso compounds are formed from nitrates in high-salt and smoked foods, Similar to tobacco smoke

Lifestyle habits

Smoking, alcohol, poor food preparation (smoked, salted), lack of refrigeration, contaminated drinking water, low socioeconomic status

Infectious Causes

H- pylori infection: M/c infectious cause of gastric cancer.

Mechanism: Chronic inflammation leading to atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma

Polyps
  • Adenomatous polyps (risk of malignancy)
  • In multiple polyps, the largest one is excised, and biopsy from others is taken.

Hereditary factors
  • E-cadherin (CDH1) gene mutation (hereditary diffuse gastric cancer) (Statement B)
  • Hereditary cancer syndromes
  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome

Medications

Proton pump inhibitors (long-term use creates low-acid environment achlorhydria; Risk for H. pylori colonisation)

Other risk factors

Gastric ulcers, pernicious anaemia (achlorhydria), obesity, Epstein-Barr virus, prior abdominal irradiation (for testicular cancer or Hodgkin’s lymphoma), prior gastric surgery, male sex

Wnt signalling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric carcinoma (Statement C): The Wnt signalling pathway plays a crucial role in developing intestinal-type gastric carcinoma. Dysregulation of this pathway can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and tumour formation.

Protective factors of Gastric carcinoma:

  • Fruits and vegetables, especially citrus fruits, help decrease the risk of the disease.
  • Exercise helps control the weight and improves muscle mass and overall health.
  • Antioxidant supplements help, too. ( beta carotene, vitamin C, vitamin A, selenium)
  • Cessation of smoking is also necessary.

It is mostly hereditary (Statement A): There are certain genetic factors that can increase the risk of developing gastric cancer, but the majority of cases are not directly linked to hereditary factors.

Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis (Statement D): The depth of cancer invasion, known as tumour staging, is an important prognostic factor in gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: An old lady sustained a fall and developed a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a fall followed by headache and neurological symptoms suggests a Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which can occur from torn bridging veins and lead to headache, altered mental status, and focal neurological deficits.

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries.

Mechanism

  
  • High-energy injury: Rupture of cortical surface vessels.
  • Low-energy injury: Venous bleeding, common in older adults on anticoagulants.

Clinical Presentation
  • Variable presentation depending on injury severity and timing.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure: Headache, reduced consciousness, focal neurological deficits.

CT Appearance

Diffuse concave hyperdense (acute), isodense (subacute), or hypodense (chronic) lesions over the brain surface, often crossing suture lines.

Management

Depends on size, location, and clinical status:

1. Large or worsening hematomas: Urgent evacuation by craniotomy or craniectomy.

2. Smaller, stable bleeds: Conservative management initially, with surgery if needed.

Multi-infarct dementia (Option A) occurs due to multiple small strokes over time, leading to gradual cognitive decline rather than acute symptoms after trauma. On imaging, multiple small infarcts are seen, often in subcortical or deep brain areas, not an acute blood collection like in a subdural hematoma.

Frontal lobe meningioma (Option B) is a slow-growing tumour that usually causes gradual symptoms like seizures or focal deficits, not acute neurological changes after a fall. On CT or MRI, it appears as a well-defined mass, often calcified, with possible brain compression, but not as an acute blood collection like in a subdural hematoma.

Korsakoff disease (Option C) is caused by chronic alcohol use leading to thiamine deficiency and results in severe memory impairment, not acute symptoms after a fall. Imaging may show brain atrophy, especially in the mammillary bodies, but no acute haemorrhage or mass effect like a subdural hematoma.

questions.text: Which one of the options listed below does not belong to the category of damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Vascular anastomosis is not typically performed during Damage Control Surgery, as the focus is on resuscitation, hemorrhage control, and stabilisation, with definitive repairs done later when the patient is stable.

 

Phases of Damage Control Surgery

Phase

Intervention

Steps

1

Recognition and Decision-making

Intubation, early rewarming, and prompt movement to operation theatre

2

Immediate Laparotomy

Control of bleeding, abdominal packing, and temporary abdominal closure

3

Intensive Care Unit

Ongoing resuscitation and normalisation of physiological and biochemical parameters

4

Re-Exploration

Definitive repair of all injuries

 

Stages of Damage Control Surgery

Stage

Intervention

1

Patient Selection

2

Control of haemorrhage and contamination (Option A, C ruled out)

3

Resuscitation in ICU (Option B ruled out)

4

Definitive Surgery

5

Abdomen closure

questions.text: A lump in the breast is observed in a female patient. Among the options listed below, all but one can be employed to exclude the presence of cancer. Which one is not applicable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
A PET scan is not typically used as a first-line test for evaluating breast lumps, as it is more commonly employed in other cancers, like lung or colorectal, to detect metastases or assess disease extent.

Triple Assessment is a combination of assessments used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis.

1. Clinical Examination (Option C ruled out)

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging (Option A ruled out)

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

(Option D ruled out)

Types:

  • FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

Triple assessment yields more accurate results than individual assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
Kallmann syndrome results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone synthesis and is associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis or hypoplasia.

 

Kallmann Syndrome:

 

Pathophysiology:
Kallmann syndrome results from defective synthesis of hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). It is often accompanied by anosmia or hyposmia due to agenesis or hypoplasia of the olfactory bulb. This defect occurs due to mutations that impair the embryonic migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus.

 

Associated Features:

  • Neurological and Physical Abnormalities:
    • Anosmia or hyposmia
    • Color blindness
    • Optic atrophy
    • Nerve deafness
    • Cleft palate
    • Cryptorchidism
    • Renal abnormalities
    • Mirror movements (neurological)

 

Genetic Basis:

  • Initial discovery: X-linked KAL gene mutations.
  • Other genetic mutations include autosomal recessive (e.g., GPR54, KISS1) and dominant (e.g., FGFR1) mutations.
  • Additional genes: GNRH1, PROK2, PROKR2, CHD7, PCSK1, FGF8, NELF, WDR11, TAC3, TACR3, SEMA3E.
  • Some cases involve oligogenic mutations where multiple gene mutations contribute to the phenotype.

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • Males: Delayed puberty, hypogonadal features (e.g., micropenis, due to low testosterone during infancy).
  • Females: Primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual development.
  • Low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and sex steroids (testosterone or estradiol).

Diagnosis:

  • Typically, it is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.
  • Repetitive GnRH administration restores pituitary gonadotropin responses, indicating a hypothalamic defect.

Treatment:

  • Males: Long-term human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or testosterone therapy to induce pubertal development and secondary sex characteristics.
  • Females: Cyclic estrogen and progestin therapy to induce secondary sexual development.
  • Fertility Restoration: Administration of gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH delivery via a portable infusion pump.

Syndactyly in males (Option B): Associated with Apert or Poland syndromes, not Kallmann syndrome.

Precocious puberty in females (Option C): Kallmann syndrome causes delayed puberty, not precocious puberty, due to deficient GnRH secretion.

White forelock (Option D): A white forelock (poliosis) is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, a genetic disorder associated with sensorineural hearing loss, pigmentary abnormalities, and dystopia canthorum but not Kallmann syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of foot measuring 3cm x 2cm
			
			
			1. Excision biopsy
			
		
		
			
			B. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck
			
			
			2. Core needle biopsy
			
		
		
			
			C. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh
			
			
			3. USG guided FNAC
			
		
		
			
			D. Solitary thyroid nodule
			
			
			4. Wedge biopsy
questions.solution:
Condition

Investigations

Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of foot measuring 3cm x 2cm

Wedge biopsy (removing a small wedge-shaped tissue sample from the nodule) is commonly performed on a Marjolin ulcer (a malignant transformation in a chronic non-healing wound).

1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck

Excision biopsy is commonly used to evaluate a lymph node.

Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh

Core needle biopsy involves obtaining a small cylindrical core of tissue from the lymph node for pathological examination.

Solitary thyroid nodule

USG guided FNAC is used to evaluate a solitary thyroid nodule by guiding a needle into the tumour to collect cells for cytological analysis.

questions.text: Which benzodiazepine is suitable for the safe administration to a 40-year-old chronic alcoholic experiencing withdrawal symptoms, based on the liver function tests that indicated AST levels of 140 IU/L, ALT levels of 110 IU/L, and GGT levels of 500 IU/L?
questions.solution:
The elevated AST and ALT levels suggest possible liver dysfunction, which is common in chronic alcoholics. Lorazepam is not extensively metabolized by the liver, and its clearance is less affected by liver dysfunction compared to other benzodiazepines. It has a shorter half-life than diazepam, making it a suitable option for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms in patients with liver disease.


 

The patient with symptoms of delirium tremens (DTs), which is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, and tremors, are commonly treated by Lorazepam. DTs can be life-threatening and require prompt treatment to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

 

Lorazepam:

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including delirium tremens.
  • Mechanism of Action: Enhances the effects of GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, which calms the central nervous system and alleviates withdrawal symptoms.
  • Advantages:
    • Relatively long half-life
    • Effective in controlling severe withdrawal symptoms
    • Suitable for patients with liver impairment
  • Metabolism: Primarily through conjugation, which is less affected by liver dysfunction compared to other benzodiazepines.
  • Lorazepam is the drug of choice for the management of status epilepticus due to its rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures.

 

Diazepam, Alprazolam, Clonazepam (Option A, B and C) are extensively metabolized by the liver and are not recommended in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: All of the following aid in the localization of the lesion to the spinal cord except?

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.solution:
Contralateral hemiplegia refers to weakness or paralysis affecting one side of the body that is opposite to the side of the lesion. However, contralateral hemiplegia is not characteristic of lesions within the spinal cord. It is more commonly associated with brainstem lesions.

 

Fasciculation at the level of the lesion (Option B) is observed at the uppermost level of the lesion in the spinal cord; it can provide clues about the involvement of the corresponding spinal cord segment.

 

UMN lesions (Option C) involve the descending motor pathways (corticospinal) originating from the brain and traveling through the spinal cord, while LMN (Option C) lesions affect the peripheral nerves or nerve roots exiting the spinal cord.

 

Bladder involvement (Option D), such as urinary retention or incontinence, can indicate dysfunction or damage to the nerves controlling bladder function within the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding shock?

choices.text: Stage of compensatory shock is also called stage 2 of shock
Anaphylactic shock—is due to a Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
• Hypovolaemic Shock is the most common type of shock.
  • It is due to a reduced circulating volume.
  • Cause:
    • Haemorrhagic
      • Injury to the liver, spleen, and bone fractures
      • Haemothorax
      • Vascular injury
      • Severe bleeding on the table during surgeries
    • Nonhaemorrhagic
      • Poor fluid intake (dehydration)
      • Excessive fluid loss due to vomiting, diarrhoea, urinary loss (e.g. diabetes)
      • Evaporation or ‘third­spacing’, where fluid is lost into the gastrointestinal tract and interstitial spaces (bowel obstruction or pancreatitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Cold and clammy skin - due to inadequate tissue perfusion.
    • Reduced renal blood flow and GFR lead to oliguria, which may lead to anuria.
    • Cerebral blood flow is reduced, leading to drowsiness and confusion.
    • Tachypnoea - due to lactic acidosis
    • Tachycardia
    • Weak thready pulse
    • Sweating
  • Classification:

Parameter

Class I (Compensated Shock)

Class II (Hypoxemia)

Class III

Class IV (Refractory Shock)

Blood Loss

Up to 15%

15-30%

30-40%

More than 40%

Mechanism

Compensatory mechanisms maintain cardiac output.

Generalised vasoconstriction.

Decompensated shock.

Refractory shock.

Heart Rate

<100/min

100-120/min

120-140/min

>140/min

Blood Pressure

Normal

Hypotension

Marked hypotension

Profound hypotension

Respiratory Rate

Normal

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Urine Output

>30 ml/hour

20-30 ml/hour

5-15 ml/hour

No urine output

Mental Status

Alert, normal

Anxious, mildly agitated

Confused, altered mental status

Comatose, lethargic

Anaerobic respiration produces carbon dioxide (Option A): Anaerobic respiration occurs in the absence of oxygen and results in the production of lactic acid, not carbon dioxide.

Stage of compensatory shock is also called stage 2 of shock (Option C): Class I refers to hypovolemic shock with up to 15% blood loss, where compensatory mechanisms sustain cardiac output, also known as Compensated Hypovolemic Shock.

Anaphylactic shock is due to Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction (Option D): Anaphylactic shocks due to Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The signs of reduced chest movement, tracheal deviation, and distended neck veins suggest a Tension Pneumothorax, which requires immediate decompression with needle thoracocentesis to relieve pressure and stabilise the patient before further interventions.

 

Tension Pneumothorax

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology
  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology
  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management
  • Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle".
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

Resuscitative thoracotomy (Option A) is used in traumatic cardiac arrest or severe haemorrhage, not for tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is urgent but not immediately fatal and should be treated with needle thoracocentesis.

ICD placement (Option B) is not the immediate treatment for tension pneumothorax, as it doesn't quickly relieve pressure. Needle thoracocentesis should be performed first, with ICD placement done afterwards for ongoing drainage.

Finger thoracotomy (Option D) is used for cardiac tamponade, not tension pneumothorax. Needle thoracocentesis is the preferred initial intervention for rapid decompression, while finger thoracotomy is reserved for later stages if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial treatment of choice for managing the condition in a female patient who comes to the hospital with palpitations, having stable vital signs and an ECG showing the following?
questions.solution:
Adenosine is the first-line management of the presented condition. The ECG pattern shown suggests Paroxysmal SupraVentricular Tachycardia (PSVT), a common arrhythmia characterized by rapid heart rates originating above the ventricles. Adenosine is a potent vasodilator and affects the electrical conduction system of the heart. It activates specific receptors in the heart, particularly the adenosine A1 receptors, which help to slow down the conduction through the AV node. This interruption of the abnormal electrical pathway in SVT can restore normal sinus rhythm.

 

Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT):

  1. Signs and Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations
    • Dizziness or lightheadedness
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest discomfort or pressure
    • Anxiety
    • Fatigue
    • In severe cases: syncope, hypotension, or heart failure symptoms
  2. ECG Findings:
    • Regular, narrow-complex tachycardia (QRS duration <120 ms)
    • Reduced R-R interval
    • Heart rate between 150-250 bpm
    • P waves often not visible or buried in T waves

 

  • Common types include:
    • a) AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT): Retrograde P waves may appear as pseudo R' in V1 or pseudo S in inferior leads
    • b) AV Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): Retrograde P waves may be visible after the QRS complex

 

  1. Management:

Acute termination:
  • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
  • If vagal maneuvers fail, IV adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment: 6 mg - 12mg fast iv push.
  • Alternative drugs: verapamil, diltiazem, or beta-blockers
  • Synchronized cardioversion for hemodynamically unstable patients

Long-term management:
  • Catheter ablation: Often curative, especially for AVNRT and AVRT
  • Pharmacological therapy:
    • Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers for prevention
    • Class IC or III antiarrhythmic drugs in selected cases
  • Patient education on performing vagal maneuvers

Lifestyle modifications
  • Avoid triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, stress)
  • Regular exercise
  • Adequate sleep

 

Amiodarone (Option A) is used to treat Stable Monomorphic Ventricular tachycardia.

 

DC Cardioversion (Option C) is used to treat Atrial flutter, Atrial fibrillatio.n

 

Primary PCI (Option D) is used to treat acute myocardial infarctio.n

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of Brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Brown-Séquard syndrome is a specific pattern of spinal cord injury characterized by a hemisection of the spinal cord (one-half of the spinal cord is damaged or severed).

Hemisection of the spinal cord (as shown in the image) results in I/L loss of Dorsal and Pyramidal column tracts and C/L loss of Spinothalamic tract (STT) 2 segments below the level of lesion is known as Brown-Sequard syndrome, as STT (specifically Lateral STT) relays at the dorsal root ganglion and crosses over at 1-2 segments above the level of that spinal cord.

Presentation of Brown-Sequard syndrome:

 

 

Ipsilateral (I/L)

Contralateral (C/L)

At the level of lesion
  • CST: LMN paralysis
  • Dorsal column: loss of vibration (Option D) and proprioception (Option B)
  • Radicular pain +
  • Muscles- fasciculation, areflexia

-

Below the level of lesion
  • CST: UMN paralysis
  • Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of Pain and Temperature (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

Explanation:

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by 14 years without the development of secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development) or by 16 years, regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

 

A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts (prepubertal breasts) would be classified as having primary amenorrhea because she has not reached the expected developmental milestones for her age.

 

Tanner Staging for Female Puberty

 

Stage

Breast Development (Thelarche)

Pubic Hair Development (Pubarche)

Stage I

Prepubertal: No breast development

Prepubertal: No pubic hair

Stage II

Breast bud forms; areola enlarges

Sparse, straight, and slightly pigmented hair along labia

Stage III

Breast tissue and areola continue to enlarge

Darker, coarser, and curlier hair on the mons pubis

Stage IV

Areola and nipple form a secondary mound above the level of the breast

Hair becomes more adult-like, but does not extend to thighs

Stage V

Adult breast contour; areola returns to normal size, nipple projects

Adult distribution of pubic hair, extends to thighs

 

Tanner Staging for Male Puberty

 

Stage

Genital Development

Pubic Hair Development

Stage I

Prepubertal: No genital development

Prepubertal: No pubic hair

Stage II

Enlargement of the scrotum and testes; skin of scrotum becomes reddened and thinner

Sparse, straight, and slightly pigmented hair at the base of the penis

Stage III

Increase in size of penis (length); further growth of testes and scrotum

Darker, coarser, and curlier hair, extending over pubis

Stage IV

Penis continues to enlarge (length and breadth); glans penis becomes more prominent

Pubic hair becomes adult-like, but does not extend to thighs

Stage V

Adult genitalia: Fully developed penis, testes, and scrotum

Adult distribution of pubic hair, extends to thighs

 

11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts (Option A): At age 11, it is still within the normal range for a girl to be in Tanner stage 1, so this would not be classified as primary amenorrhea unless menstruation has not occurred by age 14.

 

13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts (Option C): Tanner stage 5 corresponds to fully developed breasts, indicating that puberty is complete. At 13 years of age with Tanner stage 5 breasts, menstruation would typically have already occurred, so this patient would not have primary amenorrhea.

 

12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts (Option D): Tanner stage 4 represents the onset of puberty, with the breasts having developed but not fully mature. A 12-year-old in Tanner stage 4 would still be within the normal developmental range, and menstruation could be expected soon. Therefore, this would not be classified as primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation (POG) calculation:

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, the day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

Explanation:

The period of gestation (POG) is typically calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

Naegele’s Rule

 

Naegele's Rule is a standard method used to calculate the Estimated Date of Delivery (EDD) for a pregnant woman based on her Last Menstrual Period (LMP). It assumes a typical pregnancy duration of 280 days (40 weeks) from the first day of the LMP.

 

Steps to Calculate EDD Using Naegele's Rule:

  • Identify the first day of the Last Menstrual Period (LMP).
  • Add 9 months to this date or Subtract 3 months.
  • Add 7 days to the result.

 

This calculation works well for women with regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Adjustments may be needed for women with irregular cycles.

 

Example:

If the LMP is March 10, 2024:

  • Add 9 months: December 10, 2024.
  • Add 7 days: December 17, 2024.

The EDD is December 17, 2024.

 

Options A, C and D are true.

 

Option A: Ultrasound in the first trimester, especially measuring the crown-rump length (CRL), is one of the best and most accurate methods for determining gestational age during early pregnancy, typically between 7 to 12 weeks.

 

Option C: In IVF pregnancies, the day of embryo transfer or fertilization is crucial for calculating the period of gestation (POG), as the exact date of conception is known.

 

Option D: Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most reliable and accurate measurement of gestational age in the first trimester, especially between 7 to 12 weeks, as it directly reflects the fetus's size during early.

questions.text: All are long-term reversible methods of contraception, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

Female sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception. It involves surgical procedures like tubal ligation, where the fallopian tubes are either severed, destroyed, or blocked, preventing the eggs from reaching the uterus. This method is permanent and cannot be reversed, making it distinct from other long-term reversible methods.

 

Progestin injections (Option A), like NET-EN, are a form of reversible contraception. These injections prevent pregnancy for a few months and are easily reversible once discontinued.

 

Progestin implants (e.g., Nexplanon) (Option B) are small rods placed under the skin that release a hormone to prevent pregnancy. They are highly effective, reversible, and can last for several years.


Both levonorgestrel-releasing (e.g., Mirena) (Option D) and copper-containing (e.g., CuT-380A) intrauterine devices (IUDs) are long-term, reversible contraceptive methods. They can remain in place for several years and are removed if pregnancy is desired.

questions.text: The modified biophysical profile includes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) NST and AFI

 

Explanation:
The modified biophysical profile (mBPP) includes only two components:

 

NST (Nonstress Test)

Fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements

AFI (Amniotic Fluid Index)

Measurement of amniotic fluid volume

 

The mBPP is primarily used for routine surveillance, particularly in high-risk pregnancies, and takes less time (around 10 minutes).

 

Interpretation of mBPP

 

Non-reactive NST or AFI <5

Non-reassuring (abnormal result)

Reactive NST and AFI ≥ 5

Reassuring (normal result)


 

Biophysical Profile (BPP)

 

Parameter

Normal Criteria

Breathing Movements

>1 episode lasting >30 seconds

Amniotic Fluid Volume

≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes

Fetal Tone

≥1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with return of flexion (e.g., opening and closing of the hand)

Gross Body Movements

>3 discrete body/limb movements

Non-stress Test (NST)

Reactive pattern (Two accelerations of 15 seconds duration, 15 bpm, in 20 minutes)

 

BPP Scoring and Interpretation

 

BPP Score

Interpretation

Management

10

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

No action required; Routine monitoring

8

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

Repeat test weekly or biweekly for high-risk pregnancies (e.g., diabetic, post-term)

6

Possible fetal asphyxia

Repeat testing; If score ≤6, consider delivery

4

Probable fetal asphyxia

Repeat test same day or deliver if AFV is abnormal or >36 weeks

0-2

Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Immediate delivery

 

Options A, C and D: Fetal tone, breathing movements, gross fetal movements are the components of the full BPP, not the modified version, which only includes NST and AFI.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the innervation of the uterus?

choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7-T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibres at the level of T10-L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of uterine contraction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7-T8

 

Explanation:

Uterine contractions are primarily mediated by hormonal factors such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin, rather than specific innervations at T7-T8. Progesterone plays a role in relaxing the uterus. The innervation of the uterus primarily affects sensory pathways and does not directly govern uterine contractility.

 

Sage of Labor

Cause of Pain

Nerves and Plexuses Involved

Preferred Anesthesia

First Stage

(Latent Phase)

Uterine contractions and cervical dilation.

T10–L1

Sympathetic fibers from the uterine and hypogastric plexuses

None or Low-dose Epidural

First Stage

(Active Phase)

Intense uterine contractions and progressive cervical dilation.

T10–L1

Sacral plexus

Epidural Anesthesia

Spinal Anesthesia

Second Stage

Distension of the vaginal canal, pelvic floor, and perineum.

S2–S4

Pudendal nerve

Epidural Anesthesia

Spinal Anesthesia

Third Stage (Placental Phase)

Uterine contractions and manipulation during placenta expulsion or perineal repair.

S2–S4

Pudendal nerve

Local Anesthesia

 

Sensory level is from T10 to L1 (Option A): This is correct. The sensory innervation of the uterus, particularly for pain perception, involves afferent fibers passing through the inferior hypogastric plexus and entering the spinal cord at T10-T12 and L1 levels.

 

In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibres at the level of T10-L1 (Option C): This is correct. During the first stage of labor, pain is caused by the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segments, which are mediated by the sensory fibers in the T10-L1 spinal segments.

 

In early labor, pain is usually because of uterine contraction (Option D): This is correct. Pain during early labor is primarily due to the contraction of the uterus, which causes ischemia and activates nociceptors in the uterine and cervical tissues.

questions.text: Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as:

choices.text: Growth of 10^3 coliform in suprapubic sample
Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample
Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample

 

Explanation:

  • A urinary tract infection (UTI) in a pregnant woman, especially in the 2nd trimester, is defined by a positive urine culture showing a growth of >100,000 colony-forming units (CFUs) of bacteria, typically coliforms such as E. coli, in a voided urine sample. (Option A ruled out)
  • Urine culture is considered the gold standard for diagnosing UTIs in pregnancy. UTIs can range from asymptomatic bacteriuria to symptomatic infections like cystitis or pyelonephritis.

 

Frequency with dysuria with >3 WBC/HPF (Option C): While the presence of white blood cells (WBCs) in the urine indicates infection or inflammation (pyuria), this alone is not enough to define a UTI. The presence of symptoms like dysuria and WBCs along with a positive urine culture is necessary for diagnosis.

 

Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test (Option D): While a positive dipstick test for nitrites and leukocyte esterase can suggest a UTI, it is not definitive. A urine culture showing bacterial growth of 10^5 CFUs is the most reliable method for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following cerclage procedures would be done in a nonpregnant female through a transabdominal approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laparoscopic cerclage

 

Explanation:
Laparoscopic abdominal cerclage is performed in a nonpregnant woman, particularly before conception. It provides support at the internal os of the cervix and is used for women with recurrent cervical complications, failed vaginal cerclage, or a cervix too short for vaginal cerclage.


Advantages:

  • Higher placement relative to the internal os.
  • No risk of suture slippage.
  • No foreign body material in the vagina.

 

Lash and Lash cerclage (Option A) is a traditional method of transvaginal cervical cerclage, which is no longer recommended and is not used in nonpregnant women.

 

Benson and Durfee cerclage (Option B) is a transabdominal cerclage performed via laparotomy, typically used in pregnant women when the vaginal approach is not feasible.


Wurm’s cerclage (Option C) involves placing circumferential sutures transvaginally using monofilament sutures, but it is performed during pregnancy.

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except:

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels, and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, and hemorrhage and organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in sFlt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:
In preeclampsia, there is a reduced or absent production of prostacyclin (PGI2) with increased production of thromboxane (TXA2), leading to a decreased prostacyclin-to-thromboxane ratio. This causes vasoconstriction and contributes to the pathophysiology of preeclampsia.

 

Mechanisms of Preeclampsia

 

Abnormal Trophoblastic Invasion

Incomplete remodeling of spiral arteries → Narrow, high-resistance vessels → Reduced placental perfusion → Hypoxia.

Endothelial Dysfunction

sFlt-1 and endoglin release → Inhibition of VEGF and PIGF → Reduced NO production → Vasoconstriction, increased vascular permeability (proteinuria, edema). (Option B ruled out)

Imbalance in Angiogenic Factors

Increased sFlt-1, decreased VEGF and PIGF → Impaired vascular repair and angiogenesis → Endothelial injury. (Option D ruled out)

Oxidative Stress and Inflammation

Hypoxia-reoxygenation injury → ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokines → Endothelial damage, pro-thrombotic state.

Vasoconstriction and Platelet Aggregation

Decreased PGI2 (vasodilator) and increased TXA2 (vasoconstrictor) → Systemic vasoconstriction, microvascular thrombosis.

Multi-Organ Ischemia and Damage

Vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction → Reduced blood flow to:

  • Kidneys: Proteinuria (glomerular endotheliosis).
  • Liver: Hepatic ischemia, HELLP syndrome.
  • Brain: Cerebral edema, seizures (eclampsia).
  • Placenta: Fetal growth restriction, abruption. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false?

choices.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose-dependent
MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure
It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex, thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral corte,x thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

 

Explanation:
MgSO4 has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex and prevents seizures, but it does not lower blood pressure directly.

  • While MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia, it does not have a significant effect on blood pressure control. Its action is more related to neurological protection, such as stabilizing cell membranes and inhibiting calcium influx into neurons, which prevents seizures.
  • Magnesium sulfate's hypotensive effect is secondary to vascular smooth muscle relaxation, but this is not its primary use. It is not used as a first-line agent for blood pressure management, and its use for lowering blood pressure is more incidental.

 

Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4):

 

MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation.

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  • Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia.
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor)
  • Neuroprotective: Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy

Therapeutic Range

To control fits the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I

Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.

Administration and Dosage

Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.

  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment

Adjust for renal dysfunction.

 


 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Pritchard

(IV and IM)
  • Administer 4 g IV over 3-5 mins (20 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution)
  • Follow with 10 g of 50% MgSO4 solution: 5 g (10 mL of 50% solution) in each buttock as deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.
  • 5g IM with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in alternate buttocks every 4 hours; continue for 24 hours after birth or last convulsion

Zuspan

(IV only)
  • Administer 4-6 g IV over 15- 20 mins (20 mL of 20% magnesium sulfate solution).
  • If convulsions recur after 15 mins, give 2g IV (10 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution) over 5 mins.
  • 1-2 g IV infusion per hour (5 mL of 20% solution); continue for 24 hours after childbirth or last convulsion

 

Before Administration:

  • Ensure respiratory rate is at least 16 per minute (not depressed)
  • Confirm patellar reflexes are present.
  • Verify urinary output is at least 30 ml per hour over 4 hours.

 

Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity

  • Monitor magnesium sulfate toxicity by observing deep tendon reflexes, respiratory status, and urine output (primarily excreted by kidneys)
  • Impaired kidney function can lead to toxicity. Loss of patellar reflexes at ~12 mg/dL is an early warning sign.

 

Serum Magnesium Testing:

  • Routine testing is not recommended.
  • Test 4-6 hours after starting infusion to adjust rate (target: 4-7 mEq/L or 4.8-8.4 mg/dL).
  • Elevated serum creatinine (≥1.0 mg/dL) to assess kidney function.
  • Check for toxicity signs (diminished reflexes, breathing issues) to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment. Administer fluids cautiously to avoid overload and pulmonary edema.

 

Adverse Effects of Magnesium Sulfate

Mechanism:

  • Acts as a smooth muscle relaxant.

 

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

 

Management of Magnesium Toxicity:

Immediate Actions:

  • Administer 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate IV over 3 minutes to reverse mild to moderate respiratory depression.
  • Discontinue magnesium sulfate.

 

Further Steps:

  • Administer furosemide to increase urinary excretion.
  • Severe respiratory depression requires intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • The effects of IV calcium may be short-lived if steady-state toxicity is present.

 

Options A, B and D are true.

 

Option A: MgSO4 acts as a tocolytic agent by inhibiting uterine contractility, and its effect is dose-dependent. At therapeutic levels (4-7 mEq/L), MgSO4 can reduce uterine contractions, which is useful in preterm labor or in cases of eclampsia. However, at higher concentrations (above 8-10 mEq/L), it may cause adverse effects like respiratory depression.

 

Option B: MgSO4 is typically continued for 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure to prevent recurrent seizures, especially in eclampsia. This duration helps ensure adequate prophylaxis, especially since seizures can occur postpartum.

 

Option D: In patients with renal failure, the loading dose of MgSO4 (4g) can be safely administered as magnesium is excreted by the kidneys. However, the maintenance dose should be carefully adjusted based on the patient’s renal function to avoid magnesium toxicity, as the kidneys' ability to excrete magnesium is compromised in renal failure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, and blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Steroids

 

  • Explanation:
    The scenario described suggests Sheehan's syndrome, which is caused by pituitary apoplexy (hemorrhagic infarction of the pituitary) due to massive blood loss during childbirth. 
  • The treatment of choice for Sheehan’s syndrome is hormone replacement, starting with glucocorticoids (steroids), followed by other hormone replacements like thyroid hormone, sex steroids, and possibly growth hormone. 
  • Steroids are particularly critical in this emergency because they help stabilize the cardiovascular system and reverse the shock caused by adrenal insufficiency.
  • Immediate volume resuscitation and glucocorticoid therapy are essential in managing this condition.

 

Sheehan Syndrome

 

Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms

• Failure to lactate

• Hypotension

• Hypoglycemia

• fatigue

• amenorrhea

• Hypothyroidism

• adrenal insufficiency

• decreased libido

• weight gain

• cold intolerance

Diagnosis

• Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.

• Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).

• MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

 

Treatment

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)

 

Dobutamine (Option A) is a sympathomimetic drug that is used for heart failure and shock, primarily to increase cardiac output by improving contractility. However, it is not the primary treatment for Sheehan’s syndrome, which is an endocrine emergency requiring hormone replacement, particularly glucocorticoids.

 

Thyroxine (Option C) is used in the treatment of hypothyroidism, but in the case of Sheehan's syndrome, the most critical treatment initially is steroids to address acute adrenal insufficiency. Thyroxine would be required later as part of the hormone replacement regimen once the patient is stable.

 

Activated protein C (Option D) is used to treat conditions related to hypercoagulability such as sepsis-associated disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it is not indicated for Sheehan's syndrome.

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 55-85 years

Explanation:

The age group distribution for vulval cancer is most commonly between 55 and 85 years.

Vulval cancer is primarily seen in elderly women, most commonly in their 6th and 7th decades of life. The average age of diagnosis is around 65 years. (Options A, B and D ruled out)

Vulval cancer

 

Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on the disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Determines stage and prognosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Graph D

Explanation:


Graph D shows this typical pattern of glucose rise and fall, representing a normal response.

 

Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is used to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). It involves administering a 75g glucose bolus to the patient, and blood glucose is measured at specific intervals (typically at fasting, 0.5hr, 1hr, 1.5hr, and 2hr).

A normal response is characterized by:

  • Glucose Peak: A rise in blood glucose levels, peaking approximately 1 hour after glucose ingestion.
  • Return to Baseline: A gradual decline, with glucose levels returning to baseline or near baseline by 2 hours, reflecting normal insulin action.

Graph D demonstrates this expected rise and fall, indicating a normal physiological response to glucose.

Graph A (Option A): Severe DM: This graph represents a response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) in a person with severe diabetes mellitus.. In individuals with severe diabetes, the blood glucose levels are expected to be significantly elevated throughout the test, resulting in a very different curve than a normal response.

 

Graph B (Option B): Moderate DM: This graph represents a response to an OGTT in a person with moderate diabetes mellitus. Similar to Graph A, it indicates diabetes and does not represent a normal response to an OGTT.

 

LAG curve (Option C): lag storage curve. Fasting glucose level is normal. Rises rapidly in the 1/2 to 1 hour and exceeds the renal threshold and comes to normal value in minutes.

It is seen in early diabetes, hyperthyroidism.

 

Learning Objective:

 

Interpretation of OGTT

A curve is plotted by placing time on the X-axis and plasma glucose level on the Y-axis, referred to as the Glucose Tolerance Curve (GTC).

1. Normal Response
A typical normal response includes the following features:

  • Initial fasting glucose is within normal limits.
  • The highest peak value is reached within 1 hour.
  • The highest value does not exceed the renal threshold (160–180 mg/dl).
  • Fasting glucose levels are restored within 2–2.5 hours.
  • No glucose or ketone bodies are detected in any urine specimen.

2. Response of Diabetic Patients
Features include:

  • Fasting blood glucose is elevated above 110 mg/dl.
  • The highest value is reached after 1–1.5 hours.
  • The highest value exceeds the renal threshold.
  • The blood glucose level does not return to fasting levels within 2.5 hours (most characteristic feature of DM).
  • Urine samples always contain glucose (except in chronic diabetes or nephritis with raised renal thresholds).

Severity of Diabetic Curves:

  • Mildly diabetic curve
  • Moderately severe diabetic curve
  • Severe diabetic curve

3. Lag Curve for Hyperglycemia
Features include:

  • Fasting glucose level is normal.
  • Glucose rises rapidly within ½ to 1 hour, exceeding the renal threshold, leading to glucose in urine specimens.
  • Rapid and complete return to normal values.

Conditions Associated:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Pregnancy
  • Early diabetes

4. Curve for Renal Glycosuria

  • Glucose appears in the urine at levels of blood glucose much below the renal threshold.
  • Patients who show no glucosuria when fasting may have glycosuria when blood glucose is raised.

It may be seen in:

  • Renal disease and pregnancy
  • Early diabetes

 

Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group of India (DIPSI) Guidelines

 

  • Procedure: Non-fasting woman is given a 75 gm glucose load.
  • Assessment: Blood sugar levels are measured after 2 hours.

 

Sugar Value

Interpretation

>200 mg/dl

Diabetes Mellitus (DM)

140–200 mg/dl

DGGT (Deranged Gestational Glucose Tolerance)

>120 mg/dl

Indicates further investigation needed

questions.text: What is the initial indication of magnesium sulfate toxicity in a woman undergoing treatment for eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loss of knee jerk

 

Explanation:

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of knee jerk reflex. This occurs at a plasma concentration of about 7-10 meq/l.

 

Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity

 

  • Monitor magnesium sulfate toxicity by observing deep tendon reflexes, respiratory status, and urine output (primarily excreted by kidneys)
  • Impaired kidney function can lead to toxicity.
  • Loss of patellar or knee-jerk reflexes at ~12 mg/dL is an early warning sign.

 

Serum Magnesium Testing:

  • Routine testing is not recommended.
  • Test 4-6 hours after starting infusion to adjust rate (target: 4-7 mEq/L or 4.8-8.4 mg/dL).
  • Elevated serum creatinine (≥1.0 mg/dL) to assess kidney function.
  • Check for toxicity signs (diminished reflexes, breathing issues) to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment. Administer fluids cautiously to avoid overload and pulmonary edema.

 

Adverse Effects of Magnesium Sulfate

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Acts as a smooth muscle relaxant.

 

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar or knee-jerk reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

 

Management of Magnesium Toxicity:

Immediate Actions:

  • Administer 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate IV over 3 minutes to reverse mild to moderate respiratory depression.
  • Discontinue magnesium sulfate.

 

Further Steps:

  • Administer furosemide to increase urinary excretion.
  • Severe respiratory depression requires intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • The effects of IV calcium may be short-lived if steady-state toxicity is present.

 

Hypotension (Option B) is not typically the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity. While magnesium sulfate can cause some vasodilation, significant hypotension is usually a later manifestation of severe toxicity.

 

Respiratory depression (Option C) is a potential complication of magnesium sulfate toxicity, but it is not the first sign. As toxicity progresses, respiratory depression can occur, leading to shallow or slowed breathing, which can result in respiratory distress if left untreated.

 

Reduced muscle tone (hypotonia) (Option D) can occur with magnesium sulfate toxicity, but it is not typically the first sign. Hypotonia develops as toxicity worsens, affecting neuromuscular function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable option for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is primarily used for second-trimester terminations rather than for first-trimester MTP.

This method involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the amniotic sac, causing uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. It is rarely used in modern practice due to the availability of safer and more effective methods for MTP, such as mifepristone + misoprostol.


 

Methods of Termination of Pregnancy (TOP) Across Trimesters

 

Trimester

Weeks

Medical Methods

Surgical Methods

Other Methods

First

Trimester

Up to 12 weeks

Mifepristone + Misoprostol (preferred method)
  • Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)
  • Not applicable

Second

Trimester

13-20 weeks

Misoprostol alone or with mifepristone

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Extra-amniotic Ethacridine Lactate Instillation
  • Hypertonic Saline or Urea Instillation

Third

Trimester

> 20 weeks

Rarely performed; typically involves induction of labor for therapeutic reasons.

Induction with prostaglandins (e.g., misoprostol)

Feticide procedures (e.g., intracardiac injection)

questions.text: The following are correct regarding the normal placenta, except:

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:

  • Extraplacental membranes refer to the amnion and chorion, which are normal components
  • A 2-vessel umbilical cord (1 artery and 1 vein) is considered abnormal and is associated with conditions like fetal anomalies or growth restriction. The normal umbilical cord contains 3 vessels: 2 arteries and 1 vein.

General Characteristics of the Placenta

The placenta is a crucial organ in pregnancy, facilitating nutrient, gas, and waste exchange between the mother and fetus.

Shape and Size

  • Shape: Discoid, typically round to oval in shape.
  • Diameter: At term, the placenta measures approximately 22 cm in diameter. (Option B ruled out)
  • Thickness: The central thickness of the placenta at term is around 2.5 cm. (Option D ruled out)
  • Weight: The placenta weighs about 470 g at term. (Option A ruled out)

Structure

1. Chorionic Plate:

  • Found on the fetal surface.
  • Lined by the amniotic membrane.
  • The umbilical cord attaches to this surface.

2. Basal Plate:

  • Located on the maternal surface.
  • Faces the uterine wall.
  • Divided into segments called cotyledons, which are functional units of the placenta.

3. Extraplacental Membranes:

Includes the amnion and chorion, which protect and enclose the fetus.

4. Umbilical Cord:

  • Normally, it consists of three vessels: two arteries and one vein.
  • A two-vessel cord is abnormal and may indicate congenital anomalies or placental insufficiency.

Physiological Features

  • Deciduate: The placenta, along with the fetal membranes, is shed during delivery.
  • Hemochorial: Maternal blood directly contacts fetal trophoblast cells to enable efficient substance exchange.

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9 to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Explanation:

The recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9 to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE (Strategic Advisory Group of Experts) guidelines is 1 or 2 doses.

Indian Guidelines for HPV Vaccination:

Girls aged 9–14 years:

Two doses (0 and 6 months).

Girls aged 15 years and older:


 

Three doses:

  • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
  • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months.

Immunocompromised individuals (any age):

Three doses:

  • Cervarix: 0, 1, and 6 months.
  • Gardasil: 0, 2, and 6 months

WHO Guidelines for HPV Vaccination:

Girls aged 9–14 years:

One or two doses.

Girls and women aged 15–20 years:

One or two doses.

Women older than 21 years:

Two doses, 6 months apart.

 

Types and Administration of Gardasil:

 

Vaccine Type

Targeted HPV Types

Administration Schedule

Quadrivalent Gardasil

6, 11, 16, 18

Intramuscularly at 0, 2, and 6 months

Nonavalent Gardasil 9

Made from the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

Intramuscularly at 0, 2, and 6 months

 

Cervarix: The Cervarix vaccine, a bivalent HPV vaccine, is highly effective against HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the majority of cervical cancers.

 

Aspect

Details

Prevention

HPV vaccination and screening prevent most cervical cancers

Target Population

Adolescents before sexual activity

Efficacy Duration

At least ten years

Side Effects

Local pain, swelling, dizziness, headache, myalgia, anaphylaxis, lymphadenopathy

Pregnancy/Breastfeeding

Pause vaccination during pregnancy, resume post-delivery, safe during breastfeeding

Vaccine for Male

Reduces HPV risk and transmission

questions.text: The given image depicts:

choices.text: Both the succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord

 

Explanation: The abnormal placenta shown in the image depicts both a succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord.

 

The image depicts features of both abnormalities:

  • The presence of an accessory lobe confirms a succenturiate lobe.
  • The insertion of the umbilical cord into membranes rather than directly into the placenta confirms velamentous insertion.

Coexistence of these abnormalities increases the risk of obstetric complications such as:

  • Fetal bleeding in cases of vessel rupture.
  • Retained tissue after delivery leading to postpartum complications.

 

Succenturiate Lobe: A succenturiate lobe is an accessory lobe of the placenta that is separate from the main placental body but connected by blood vessels.

Clinical Relevance:

  • Can lead to complications such as retained placental tissue after delivery, increasing the risk of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • If unrecognized, it might result in infection or delayed uterine involution.
  • It may also interfere with the normal course of delivery if the lobe remains in the uterus.

Velamentous Insertion of the Cord: Velamentous insertion occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (chorioamniotic membranes) instead of the placental disk. The blood vessels then traverse unprotected (unsupported by Wharton's jelly) before reaching the placenta.

 

 

Clinical Relevance:

  • Increases the risk of vasa previa, a condition where fetal blood vessels pass near or over the cervical os, leading to high risk of vessel rupture during labor.
  • May result in compromised blood flow to the fetus, potentially causing growth restriction or stillbirth.
  • Prone to trauma during delivery, leading to significant fetal hemorrhage.

 

Abnormalities of Placenta:

 

Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

• Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.

• It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

• Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.

• The spectrum has 3 conditions: 

◦ Accreta

◦ Increta

◦ Percreta

• It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits are associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

 

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

 

Battledore Placenta

An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the centre.

It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labour and fetal distress.

Placenta spuria

Unequal placenta not connected by vessel

Succenturiate lobe (Option A): A succenturiate lobe is an accessory lobe of the placenta connected to the main placenta by blood vessels. While this abnormality is present, it alone does not describe the findings in the image.

 

Velamentous insertion of the cord (Option B): In velamentous insertion, the umbilical cord attaches to the membranes rather than directly to the placental disc. This feature is visible in the image, but it is not the sole abnormality depicted.

 

Normal placenta (Option D): The findings in the image are not consistent with a normal placenta, ruling out this option.

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by the placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) hCG

 

Explanation:

hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) is a glycoprotein hormone secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.

It can be detected in the maternal blood and urine as early as 8–9 days post-fertilization using techniques like radioimmunoassay. During early pregnancy, hCG levels double every 1.4–2 days.

 

Functions of hCG:

 

  • Rescue of the Corpus Luteum: The primary role of hCG is to stimulate the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during the first 6 weeks of pregnancy, maintaining the uterine environment.
  • Leydig Cell Stimulation: It stimulates Leydig cells in the male fetus to produce testosterone, which is crucial for male sexual differentiation.
  • Steroidogenesis: hCG supports steroid hormone production by the adrenal glands and placenta.
  • Thyrotropic Activity: It stimulates the maternal thyroid gland due to its structural similarity to TSH, leading to mild thyroid activation during pregnancy.
  • Relaxin Secretion: hCG promotes the secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum, which helps in softening the cervix and ligaments in late pregnancy.

 

Clinical Implications of hCG Levels:

  • High hCG levels: Associated with multiple pregnancies, hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma, and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).
  • Low hCG levels: Seen in ectopic pregnancies and impending miscarriages.

 

LH (Luteinizing Hormone) (Option A) is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, not the placenta. It plays a crucial role in ovulation and maintaining the corpus luteum.

 

FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) (Option C) is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and is involved in stimulating ovarian follicle development in females and spermatogenesis in males, but it is not produced by the placenta.

 

GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) (Option D) is secreted by the hypothalamus and regulates the secretion of LH and FSH; however, it is unrelated to placental function.

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital syphilis

 

Explanation:

Kassowitz rule pertains to congenital syphilis and describes the impact of untreated syphilis in successive pregnancies.

 

Kassowitz Rule: The rule states that if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the risk of fetal infection decreases with each subsequent pregnancy. In the first pregnancy, the outcome is usually an abortion. In subsequent pregnancies, the outcomes may involve stillbirths, and eventually, later pregnancies can result in live births with congenital syphilis.

 

Congenital Syphilis:
Congenital syphilis occurs when Treponema pallidum is transmitted from an infected mother to the fetus, leading to complications like fetal death, preterm labor, and stillbirth if untreated.

 

Transmission Routes

  • Transplacental (through the placenta)
  • Perinatal (during delivery)

 

Clinical Features

  • Jaundice
  • Ascites
  • Petechiae and Purpura
  • Pneumonia
  • Myocarditis
  • Long Bone Involvement

 

Treatment: Penicillin

questions.text: Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent congenitally in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cystic fibrosis

 

Explanation: In cystic fibrosis, there is a congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD).

  • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to abnormally thick and viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages. CBAVD can be the only clinical feature suggesting a CFTR mutation.
  • On examination, the reproductive tract appears normal except for the bilateral absence of the vas deferens and atrophic or absent seminal vesicles.
  • Men with CF also present with azoospermia (no sperm in the semen), low-volume ejaculate, and a lack of seminal vesicle fluid, which normally contains fructose.
  • Some patients may also have associated renal agenesis.

 

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B) is a genetic disorder with a 47, XXY karyotype, leading to infertility due to seminiferous tubule hyalinization and small testes. However, it does not typically cause the bilateral absence of seminal vesicles or vas deferens.

 

Kallmann syndrome (Option C) is characterized by hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of smell) due to a deficiency in GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone), leading to delayed or absent puberty and infertility. While it causes infertility, it does not lead to the absence of the seminal vesicles or vas deferens.

 

Kartagener syndrome (Option D) affects ciliary motility and is characterized by situs inversus (reversal of organ position), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. Infertility in males results from immotile sperm (asthenospermia) rather than structural absence of seminal vesicles or vas deferens.

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:
Except for echocardiography for cardiac disease, all other tests (urine analysis for bacteriuria, blood sugar levels for GDM, and VDRL for syphilis) are cost-effective investigations routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers.

 

Echocardiography is an expensive investigation not routinely recommended for all pregnant women but is indicated in specific conditions such as:

  • Abnormal genetic screening results (e.g., increased nuchal translucency >3 mm), requiring detailed ultrasound and fetal echocardiography.
  • Gestational diabetes mellitus, for early detection of fetal anomalies, typically performed at 20-22 weeks.
  • Maternal heart disease (e.g., congenital heart disease, Marfan's syndrome), to assess structural abnormalities or valve anatomy.

 

Routine Investigations During Pregnancy:

 

Trimester

Investigations

First Trimester
  • Hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Blood grouping and Rh typing
  • Blood glucose testing
  • VDRL testing
  • Midstream urine analysis (protein, sugar, nitrites)
  • Serology for rubella, hepatitis B, and HIV
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (optional)
  • Ultrasound (Dating Scan): Confirms gestational age, fetal viability, and number of fetuses
  • Pap smear (if not done within the last year)

Second Trimester
  • Ultrasound (Anomaly Scan, 18–20 weeks): Assesses fetal anatomy, structural abnormalities, amniotic fluid index, and placental location
  • Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT, 24–28 weeks)
  • Repeat urine analysis
  • Quadruple marker screening (optional)
  • Antibody screening (for Rh-negative mothers)
  • Ultrasound (Fetal Echocardiography, if indicated): Detailed evaluation of fetal heart for congenital anomalies

Third Trimester
  • Repeat hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Repeat serology for syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis B
  • Vaginal and rectal swab for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) testing (35–37 weeks)
  • Ultrasound (Growth Scan): Monitors fetal growth, amniotic fluid levels, and placental function
  • Non-stress test (NST) or biophysical profile (BPP, if indicated)
  • Coagulation profile (if indicated)
  • Ultrasound (Doppler Scan, if indicated): Evaluates placental and fetal blood flow in conditions like IUGR or preeclampsia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of diabetes in pregnancy?

choices.text: Elective C-section has no role in reducing the incidence of brachial plexus injury.
In a patient being planned for induction of labor, the night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld.
In active labor, if RBS 100 mg%.
Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 hr postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 hrs postprandial- 120 mg%.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Elective C-section has no role in reducing the incidence of brachial plexus injury.

 

Explanation:

An elective C-section has been shown to be protective against traumatic injuries, such as brachial plexus injury, particularly in macrosomic babies born to mothers with diabetes.

 

Indications for C-section in diabetic pregnancies include fetal macrosomia (>4.5 kg), unsatisfactory labor progression, complicated diabetes, fetal compromise, and other obstetric complications like preeclampsia or polyhydramnios.

 

Statement B is true: In planned deliveries, the bedtime dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given, but the morning dose is withheld due to reduced insulin requirements post-delivery.

 

Statement C is true: During active labor, if RBS is <70 mg%, 5% dextrose (D5) is administered at 100-150 ml/hr to maintain RBS levels above 100 mg%. Before labor initiation, normal saline is typically used for IV infusion.

 

Statement D is true: This statement is true. Capillary blood glucose goals for pregnant women with diabetes are:

  • Fasting: ≤95 mg/dL
  • 1-hour postprandial: ≤140 mg/dL
  • 2-hour postprandial: ≤120 mg/dL.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy?

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy should be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High-dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy are safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

Option D is incorrect because methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and not safe during pregnancy.

These drugs should be avoided in pregnant women due to their potential to cause fetal malformations and other serious developmental effects.

 

  • Methotrexate: A folate antagonist; avoid during pregnancy due to risk of fetal malformations, including neural tube defects and craniofacial anomalies.
  • Cyclophosphamide: A cytotoxic drug; teratogenic and should only be used in pregnancy when absolutely necessary.

 

Other drugs mentioned in the list, such as ecospirin (low-dose aspirin), corticosteroids, and azathioprine, are considered relatively safer in pregnancy and are often used in managing lupus nephritis during pregnancy.

 

  • Ecospirin (low-dose aspirin): Considered safer in pregnancy; used for anticoagulant effects, especially in antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • Corticosteroids: Safe during pregnancy when appropriately managed; used for lupus flares, but higher doses may increase the risk of gestational diabetes or preterm birth.
  • Azathioprine: Safe for use in severe SLE cases during pregnancy and can be continued if needed.

 

Lupus Nephritis in Pregnancy

 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder that commonly affects young women. Lupus nephritis refers to kidney involvement in SLE, which can complicate pregnancy.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Fever, weight loss, migratory joint pain, myalgias.
  • Risks: Preterm birth, preeclampsia, pregnancy loss, neonatal lupus (heart block).

 

Diagnosis:

  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) for screening.
  • Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) for specific diagnosis.
  • Lupus anticoagulant, antiphospholipid antibodies, anti-Ro, and anti-La antibodies may indicate antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Management of Lupus Nephritis in Pregnancy:

 

Preconception Planning:

Pregnancy should be planned 6 months after disease quiescence with no renal dysfunction.

 

Medications:

  • Corticosteroids: Safe for managing lupus flares during pregnancy.
  • Azathioprine: Safe for severe SLE and can be continued.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Best for maintenance, safe in pregnancy.

 

Avoid:

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and should not be used during pregnancy.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF): The "boot-shaped heart" (coeur en sabot) seen on a chest radiograph is a classic finding in TOF. It occurs due to:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which causes the apex of the heart to lift upward.
  • Pulmonary artery hypoplasia or stenosis, which accentuates the shape.
    TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, characterised by the four features:
  1. Pulmonary stenosis
  2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  3. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  4. Overriding aorta

Chest X-ray Imaging in TOF:

  • The classic finding on a chest X-ray for TOF is the “boot-shaped” heart (also known as coeur en sabot), caused by right ventricular hypertrophy leading to an upward tilt of the cardiac apex. There is often a concave main pulmonary artery and decreased pulmonary vascular markings, reflecting the reduced blood flow through the pulmonary arteries due to the RVOT obstruction.
  • Some patients may also present with a right-sided aortic arch, which can be identified on the X-ray.

 

 

Ebstein’s anomaly (option B): This is incorrect because the radiographic finding in Ebstein’s anomaly is an enlarged, "box-shaped" heart due to massive right atrial enlargement, not a boot shape.

 

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) (option C): This is incorrect because TGA typically shows an "egg-on-string" appearance on chest X-ray, with a narrow mediastinum.


Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) (option D): This is incorrect because TAPVC commonly shows a "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign due to dilated veins and a vertical vein, not a boot-shaped heart.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?

1. Interlobular septations

2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation

3. Pleural effusion

4. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Answer: A) 1,2,4

 

Explanation:

Interlobular septations (1): Fungal pneumonia can cause thickening of interlobular septa due to inflammation or oedema, particularly in invasive fungal infections like mucormycosis or aspergillosis.

Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation (2): A hallmark of angioinvasive fungal infections (e.g., Aspergillus) is peripheral, wedge-shaped areas of consolidation due to vascular infarction.

Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (4): Known as the "halo sign," this finding is common in invasive aspergillosis, where necrosis leads to cavitation surrounded by haemorrhage.
