questions.text: What microscopy technique is utilized to generate a high contrast image of transparent, viable bacteria?
questions.solution:
Phase contrast microscopy is a technique that produces high-contrast images.

  • This microscope creates a contrast between living cells and water by converting slight differences in refractive index and cell density into detectable variations in light intensity, allowing for visualization of unstained cells.
  • It enables background light to be separated from specimen-diffracted light.
  • Microbial motility.
  • Determining the shape of living cells.
  • Detecting bacterial components such as endospores and inclusion bodies.
  • Reveal internal structures of living cells.

 

Darkfield microscope

  • Light is reflected.
  • Illuminates the objects.
  • Used for thin structures:
  • Flagella
  • Spirochetes

 

Interference contrast microscope

  • Reveals cell organelles.
  • Measurements of chemical constituents of cells such as:
  • Lipids
  • Proteins
  • Nucleic acids

 

Fluorescence microscope

  • Light source: UV light
  • Uses: cases of TB/ malaria/pathology of kidney biopsy
  • Immunofluorescence + fluorescent dye

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus which differ from bacteria by having rigid cell walls containing chitin, mannan and polysaccharides. Cytoplasmic membrane contains sterols.

 

Property

Fungi

Bacteria
  1. Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote
  1. Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid
  1. Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols are present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols are absent except in Mycoplasma
  1. Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent
  1. Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome
  1. Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm
  1. Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching
  1. Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

 

Clinical implications:

  • Beta 1,3 glucan Antigenin serum for invasive fungal infections except Cryptococcus and Mucor/Rhizopus
  • Galactomannan test for invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibit genetic re assortment?
questions.solution:
Virus which have segmented genome will show genetic reassortment in which co-infection of a host cell with multiple viruses results in the shuffling of gene segments to generate progeny viruses with novel genome combinations.

  • Reassortment is exclusively seen in viruses with a segmented genome.
  • It is defined as the exchange of intact genes within the entire segment, which occurs during confection.

 

Orthomyxovirus (Influenza Virus) Segments and Structure:

 

  • Genera: Includes influenza A, B, C, and D viruses.
  • Genome Segments:
    • Influenza A and B: Eight segments of negative-sense, single-stranded RNA.
    • Influenza C and D: Seven segments (lacking the segment coding for neuraminidase).
  • Shape and Size:
    • Spherical, approximately 80–120 nm in diameter.
    • Helical symmetry with a helical nucleocapsid enclosed in an envelope.
  • Replication Site:
    • Unique among RNA viruses, replication occurs in the nucleus.
  • Viral Proteins:
    • Structural Proteins:
      • Polymerase proteins: PB1, PB2, and PA are responsible for RNA transcription and replication.
      • Nucleoprotein (NP): Forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with viral RNA.
      • Matrix proteins: M1 forms a shell beneath the envelope; M2 forms ion channels in the envelope.
      • Glycoproteins: Hemagglutinin (HA) binds sialic acid receptors for viral entry; Neuraminidase (NA) aids in viral release and prevents virion aggregation.
    • Non-structural Proteins:
      • NS1 acts as an interferon antagonist.
      • NS2 aids in nuclear export.
  • Envelope:
    • Lipid envelope containing HA and NA glycoproteins, which are essential for host cell entry and virus release.
    • Hemagglutinin:
      • Triangular-shaped peplomer.
      • Binds to mucin or sialic acid receptors on respiratory epithelial cells.
      • Facilitates viral entry into host cells.
    • Neuraminidase:
      • Mushroom-shaped and present in fewer numbers than HA.
      • Sialidase enzyme that degrades sialic acid receptors on host cells.
      • Facilitates release of virus particles from infected cell surfaces during budding.
      • Prevents self-aggregation of virions to host cells.
      • Helps the virus pass through the mucin layer in the respiratory tract to reach target epithelial cells.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is incorrect?

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction.
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent.
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy.

questions.solution:
Given CT scan is that of Renal Hydatid Cyst showing cystic structures surrounded by a rim of calcifications.

  • FNAC or biopsy should never be done before nephrectomy in case of a hydatid cyst as it contains lots of hydatid fluid, which can produce an anaphylactic reaction in the patient.

 

Management of Echinococcus granulosus

Management is guided by the WHO classification (CE1-CE5) and depends on cyst stage, location, symptoms, and complication risk.

Pharmacotherapy

Albendazole and Praziquantel:

  • Albendazole is the drug of choice for uncomplicated cysts, used to prevent recurrence and to reduce the size of the cyst before surgery or PAIR.
  • Praziquantel serves as an adjunct therapy to enhance treatment efficacy.

 

PAIR Technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration): Best mode of treatment of cysts

 

Steps:

  1. Puncture: Insert needle into cyst under ultrasound or CT guidance.
  2. Aspiration: Partially aspirate cyst fluid to reduce pressure.
  3. Injection: Inject scolicidal agent (e.g., hypertonic saline, ethanol, cetrimide) into cyst.
  4. Reaspiration: Re-aspirate injected fluid to remove cyst contents and scolicidal agent.

 

  • Minimally Invasive: Effective for unilocular cysts (CE1 and CE3a); involves puncturing and injecting a scolicidal agent.
  • Advantages: Lower recurrence risk and shorter hospital stays.
  • Contraindications: Not suitable for
    • Cysts with extensive daughter cysts or at risk of rupture
    • Calcified cyst

 

Percutaneous Drainage (PERC): An alternative to PAIR for draining cysts without scolicidal agents.

 

Surgical Management

Cystectomy or Pericystectomy:

For large, complicated, or ruptured cysts; it is preferred for CE2 and CE3b cysts or challenging anatomical locations.

 

Watch and Wait:

Inactive or Calcified Cysts (CE4 and CE5) can often be observed safely with regular imaging follow-up.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in the anaemia of chronic disease, except:
questions.solution:
In anaemia of chronic disease, ferritin levels are typically normal or elevated due to the inflammatory response, while hepcidin levels are increased, leading to impaired iron absorption and reduced availability of iron for erythropoiesis.

 

Anaemia of Chronic Disease (AOCD):

  • Interleukin-6 is the most important inflammatory mediator linked to the pathogenesis of anaemia of chronic disease (AOCD).
  • In chronic conditions, Interleukin-6 will increase and act on the liver.
  • Releases Hepcidin (Master regulator of Iron metabolism)
    • Inhibits Fe absorption.
    • Serum iron levels and transferrin saturation are decreased.
    • Inhibits the release of Fe from ferritin. Therefore, ferritin levels increase.
    • This leads to a decrease in TIBC.

Anemia

Serum Iron

Transferrin saturation

Serum Ferritin

TIBC

Sideroblastic Anemia

High

High

High

Low

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Low

Low

Low

High

Anaemia of Chronic Disease

Low

Low

High

Low

Hemolytic Anemia

High

Low

High

Low

questions.text: Neurosecretory bodies are seen in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Neurosecretory bodies are collections of secretory granules, typically seen in tumours that arise from neuroendocrine cells, such as medullary thyroid carcinoma, pituitary adenoma, and paraganglioma. However, adrenal cortical tumours originate from the adrenal cortex and do not typically contain neurosecretory bodies.

 

Adrenocortical Neoplasms:

  • It causes various forms of hyperadrenalism, including both adenomas and carcinomas.
  • These tumours are common in adults, with carcinomas being more prevalent in children.
  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome (due to TP53 mutations) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (linked to IGF-2 overexpression) increase the risk for adrenocortical carcinoma.

 

Types of Adrenocortical Neoplasms:

  • Functional adenomas:
    • It often causes hyperaldosteronism or Cushing syndrome, with virilizing neoplasms usually being carcinomas.
    • Some neoplasms do not secrete hormones; their functionality is assessed via clinical evaluation and hormone testing.
  • Nonfunctional Adenomas:
    • Usually asymptomatic, often detected incidentally.
    • Small, well-circumscribed lesions (up to 2.5 cm) have a normal surrounding adrenal cortex and are yellow-brown due to lipid content.
    • Microscopically, they resemble normal adrenal cortex cells with minimal mitotic activity and a Ki-67 index < 5%.
  • Adrenocortical Carcinomas:
    • Rare and typically more functional than adenomas, often associated with virilism and other hyperadrenalism symptoms.
    • These large, invasive tumours (>20 cm) can invade the adrenal vein, vena cava, and lymphatics, with frequent metastases to regional nodes and distant organs.
    • Survival rates are low, with a median of 2 years.

 

Neuroendocrine tumors:

  • Carcinoid tumor
  • Pituitary adenoma (Option B)
  • Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor (PanNET)
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) (Option A)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Paraganglioma (Option C)
  • Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)
  • Large Cell Neuroendocrine Carcinoma (LCNEC)
  • Neuroblastoma

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney?


	Most common primary renal malignancy
	Associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3
	Not associated with paraneoplastic syndrome
	The classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is seen.
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including hypercalcemia, erythrocytosis, and hypertension.

 

Clear cell carcinoma:

  • Prevalence: Accounts for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. (Most common)
  • Tumour Characteristics: Composed of cells with clear or granular cytoplasm and a nonpapillary pattern.
  • Familial vs. Sporadic: Primarily sporadic (95%), but can also be familial.
  • Genetic Alterations:
    • Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3 in 98% of cases.
    • The VHL gene, located in this region, is a key tumour suppressor gene.
  • Classic triad of flank pain, palpable mass, and hematuria is commonly observed in kidney tumours, although it may not be present in all cases.
  • Morphology:
    • Origin: Arises from proximal tubular epithelium.
    • Gross Appearance:
      • Bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses.
      • Yellow colour due to lipid accumulation in tumour cells.
      • It may have areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and cystic regions.
  • Histopathology:
  • Most tumours are well-differentiated & some may show nuclear atypia, bizarre nuclei, and giant cells.
  • The growth pattern varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular (resembling tubules).
  • The tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm containing glycogen and lipids.
  • The tumours have delicate branching vasculature and may show cystic and solid areas.

questions.text: Differential expression of a gene depending upon the parent of origin is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Genomic imprinting refers to the phenomenon where the expression of a gene depends on which parent the gene was inherited from. In imprinted genes, one allele is silenced depending on the parent of origin, leading to differential expression.

 

Genomic imprinting:

  • Inheritance: We inherit two copies of each autosomal gene, one from each parent, but functional differences can exist between the maternal and paternal alleles.
  • Mechanism: Imprinting is an epigenetic process that selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Maternal imprinting silences the maternal allele, while paternal imprinting silences the paternal allele.
  • Imprinting occurs in the ovum or sperm before fertilization.
  • The imprinting pattern is stably transmitted to somatic cells through mitosis.
  • Imprinting is linked to disorders like Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.


 

Prader-Willi syndrome

Chromosome 15q

SNORP gene
  • Paternal deletion
  • Maternal imprinting

Angelman syndrome

Chromosome 15q

UBE3A gene
  • Maternal deletion
  • Paternal imprinting

 

Gonadal mosaicism (Option A) refers to a condition where some of an individual's gametes (eggs or sperm) carry a mutation that is not present in the somatic cells. It does not involve differential expression based on the parent of origin, which is specific to genomic imprinting.

 

Anticipation (Option C) refers to the phenomenon where a genetic disorder becomes more severe or appears at an earlier age with each successive generation. It is seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders.

 

Incomplete penetrance (Option D) refers to situations where an individual with a disease-causing genotype does not show the expected phenotype.

Example: BRCA1 gene mutations, which increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Some individuals with the mutation never develop cancer despite carrying the gene.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and MIC2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option B)

Explanation

The clinical scenario, along with the image showing small, round, uniform cells and positive immunohistochemistry for synaptophysin and MIC2 (CD99) in the diaphysis of long bones like the tibia, is characteristic of Ewing sarcoma.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma:

  • It is a malignant bone tumour characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation.
  • Approximately 80% of patients are younger than 20 years of age.
  • Males are affected slightly more often than Females.
  • It usually arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and in the flat bones of the pelvis, and presents as a painful, enlarging mass.
  • The most common mutation (>90% of the cases) is t(11;22)(q24;q12).
  • Morphology:
    • The tumour is soft, tan-white, and frequently contains areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.
    • It comprises sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm that may be clear due to abundant glycogen.
    • Homer-Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) are rounded cell clusters with a central fibrillary core; their presence indicates neuroectodermal differentiation.
    • Specific markers: CD99+ (MIC2) positive.
    • Fibrous septae may also be present, but there is little stroma.
    • Geographic necrosis may be prominent.
  • Chemotherapy-induced necrosis is a positive prognostic indicator.

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) is a type of bone cancer originating from cells that produce new bone tissue. It often presents with pain and swelling in the affected bone, and X-rays may show a characteristic "sunburst" or "spiculated" appearance. Histologically, osteosarcoma is characterized by the production of osteoid, a bone-like substance formed by the tumour cells.

Metastatic Neuroblastoma (Option C) is a cancer that develops from immature nerve cells and most commonly occurs in young children. It can originate in areas like the adrenal glands or nerve tissues in the neck, chest, or abdomen. While it may metastasize to the bone and cause lytic lesions, it is not typically associated with a periosteal reaction or positive immunohistochemistry for synaptophysin and MIC2.

Osteoclastoma (Option D), also known as a giant cell tumour of bone, is a benign tumour that mainly affects young adults. It is characterized by multinucleated giant cells and osteoclast-like cells. X-rays usually show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance. However, it is not typically associated with a periosteal reaction or positive immunohistochemical findings for synaptophysin and MIC2.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
B lymphocytes are part of adaptive immunity, as they are involved in antibody production and the adaptive immune response.

 

Difference between innate and acquired immunity

Innate/native immunity

Acquired/adaptive immunity

Present since birth.

Occurs after exposure to the pathogen.

Quick, non-specific response.

Slower, specific response to a pathogen.

No immunological memory.

Has immunological memory.

Examples include:

  • Epithelial barriers like skin, GIT.
  • Plasma proteins like C-reactive protein.
  • Neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, complement system.

Cells are of 2 types:

  • B lymphocytes: Provides humoral immunity and produces antibodies.
  • T lymphocytes: Involved in cell-mediated immunity and help with immunity against intracellular microbes.

 

Alpha defensins (Option A) are small peptides produced by Neutrophils, Paneth cells, and other cells involved in innate immunity. They have antimicrobial properties and can directly kill bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

Gamma delta T lymphocytes (Option C) are a subset of T cells with innate-like functions. They can recognize and respond to a broad range of antigens, including those not processed or presented by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC).

Lectin pathway (Option D) is a part of the complement system in innate immunity. It is activated when lectin proteins bind to carbohydrates on the surface of pathogens, leading to complement activation and the formation of membrane attack complexes that can lyse the pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
questions.solution:
Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern, primarily affecting females.

 

X-linked dominant inheritance:

  • The gene responsible for the concerned trait or disorder is present on the X chromosome and can express itself both in homozygous and heterozygous conditions.
  • It is more commonly seen in females than males since females have two X chromosomes.
  • An affected male will transmit the disease to all his daughters but not sons.
  • An affected female can transmit the disease to both daughters and sons.
  • Conditions with X-linked dominant inheritance:
  • Rett syndrome.
  • Alport syndrome
  • Vitamin D-resistant rickets.
  • Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

The pedigree chart below shows an X-linked dominant pattern:

  • The affected mother of the first generation transmitted the disease to both son and daughter.
  • The affected father of the second generation transmitted the disease only to the daughters.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option B) follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Huntington’s disease (Option C) follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D) is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Learning Objective:

  • X-linked dominance is more common in females.
  • Affected males transmit the disease only to their daughters.
  • Affected females transmit the disease to both daughters and sons.

questions.text: Cell-in-cell appearance is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Entosis refers to the process where one cell is engulfed by another, leading to a "cell-in-cell" appearance.

 

Entosis:

  • It refers to a homotypic process where one epithelial cell invades the cytoplasm of another epithelial cell.
  • The host cell forms a vacuole around the internalized cell, which deforms its organelles, including the nucleus.
  • The inner cell may survive within the host cell for up to 12 hours or longer, eventually being digested by the outer cell through an autophagosomal mechanism, or it may escape.

Necrosis (Option A) is an uncontrolled form of cell death characterized by cell swelling, rupture, and inflammation.

 

Apoptosis (Option B) is a controlled, programmed cell death where cells shrink and fragment into apoptotic bodies.

 

Necroptosis (Option C) is a form of regulated cell death that mimics necrosis but is genetically controlled. Unlike apoptosis, it is associated with inflammation and occurs via receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3), leading to membrane rupture and the release of intracellular contents.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma?
questions.solution:
Perineural invasion is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma, as it is a benign tumour. Perineural invasion occurs in carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, a malignant transformation of pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Pleomorphic Adenoma:

  • Most common salivary gland neoplasm: Represents ~60% of parotid tumours, less common in submandibular and minor salivary glands.
  • Benign tumour: Composed of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells (also called mixed tumour).
  • Risk factors: Radiation exposure increases risk. Chromosomal rearrangements, including overexpression of PLAG1 and mutations in HMGA2, are commonly associated.
  • Clinical presentation: Painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses, usually in the parotid, submandibular, or buccal cavity.
  • Recurrence: 4% recurrence rate after parotidectomy; 25% after simple enucleation due to tumour extension beyond the capsule.
  • Malignant transformation: Occurs more often with the age of the lesion. 2% of tumours present <5 years develop malignancy; 10% present >15 years develop malignancy, usually adenocarcinomas or undifferentiated carcinomas.
  • Aggressive cancers: If malignant transformation occurs, cancers are highly infiltrative, with a 30-50% mortality rate at 5 years.
  • Morphology:
    • Size: Typically rounded, well-demarcated masses <6 cm.
    • Histological features: Heterogeneous morphology with ductal, acinar, tubule-like structures, and myoepithelial cells (Option A). Background of myxoid, hyaline, and chondroid stroma (Option C) (cartilage-like areas). Rare bone foci. No significant epithelial dysplasia or mitotic activity.
    • Tumour behaviour: Similar clinical course regardless of whether epithelial or mesenchymal elements dominate.
    • Keratin pearls (Option B): While rare, keratin pearls can occasionally be observed in pleomorphic adenoma, especially when there is squamous metaplasia within the tumour.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding sirtuins?


	Increases insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism
	Promotes genes that increase longevity
	They are of 7 types
	They are one of the types of histone deacetylases
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. (Statement 4)
  • Seven types (Statement 3) of sirtuins exist in mammals, each with unique functions.
  • They help the body adapt to environmental stresses like food deprivation and DNA damage.
  • Longevity: Sirtuins promote genes that increase longevity (Statement 2), reduce metabolism, inhibit apoptosis, and protect against oxidative damage.
  • Sirtuins enhance insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism (Statement 1)
  • Caloric restriction: Increases sirtuin activity, reducing IGF-1 signalling, leading to slower cell growth, reduced metabolism, and cellular damage.
  • Sirtuin-6: Plays a key role in metabolic adaptations and DNA repair by activating repair enzymes.
  • Anti-ageing: Sirtuins are linked to anti-ageing effects.
  • Red wine: A compound in red wine is believed to activate sirtuins, potentially contributing to increased lifespan.

questions.text:
Match the following cells with their locations:

 


	
		
			
			Cells
			
			
			Locations
			
		
		
			
			1. Kupffer cells
			
			
			a. Stomach
			
		
		
			
			2. Parietal cells
			
			
			b. Liver
			
		
		
			
			3. Dust cells
			
			
			c. Alveoli
			
		
		
			
			4. Clara cells
			
			
			d. Bronchioles
questions.solution:
Cells

Locations

Kupffer cells

Liver

Parietal cells

Stomach

Dust cells

Alveoli

Clara cells

Bronchioles

 

  • Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver. They are part of the liver's immune system and help filter blood and remove pathogens and debris.
  • Parietal cells are found in the stomach lining and secrete hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factors, which are essential for digestion and absorption of vitamin B12.
  • Dust cells: These are alveolar macrophages located in the lungs, specifically in the alveoli. They play a role in clearing out inhaled particles, bacteria, and debris from the lungs.
  • Clara cells are located in the bronchioles (small air passages in the lungs), protect the lungs from oxidative stress and have a role in detoxification by secreting various substances, including surfactant components.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in the Th1 response?
questions.solution:
IL-4 is primarily associated with the Th2 response, not the Th1 response. It promotes the differentiation of T cells into Th2 cells and is involved in humoral immunity and allergic responses.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient with a history of smoking 24 packs, currently experiencing breathlessness and chest pain, and found to have a lung tumour with positive chromogranin staining?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation and positive staining for neuroendocrine markers such as Chromogranin and synaptophysin are highly suggestive of Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) originating from neuroendocrine cells.

  • It is a highly malignant form of lung cancer associated with smoking and is known for its aggressive behaviour and early metastasis.
  • The genetic landscape of SCLC typically involves the inactivation of TP53 and RB genes.
  • L-MYC amplification is a common feature in some SCLC cases, contributing to the tumour's rapid growth and aggressive nature.

 

Characteristic

Small Cell Carcinoma

Squamous Cell Carcinoma
(Option B)

Carcinoid Tumor

Adenocarcinoma
(Option A)

Origin

Neuroendocrine cells of the lung.

Squamous cells of the lung.

Neuroendocrine cells of bronchial epithelium.

Glandular cells of the lung.

Cells in histopathology

Small, round to oval, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and finely granular chromatin with a “salt and pepper” appearance.

Sheets of polygonal cells with keratinization and intercellular bridges

Nesting (organoid) growth pattern with uniform round nuclei, moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a “salt-and-pepper” chromatin pattern.

Glandular or epithelial cells forming acinar, papillary, or solid patterns

Mitotic rate

High

Variable

Low to moderate

Variable

Electron microscopy findings

Dense core neurosecretory granules.

Desmosomes, tonofilaments, keratinisation

Dense core neurosecretory granules.

Variable organelles, sometimes containing mucin vacuoles

IHC markers

Positive for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin).

P63, p40, CK5/6

Positive for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin)

Variable (e.g., TTF-1, Napsin A for primary lung adenocarcinoma)

Mesothelioma (Option C) is a cancer associated with asbestos exposure, not typically associated with smoking. Additionally, it does not usually show chromogranin positivity. It usually arises from the pleura and presents with different symptoms, such as pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath.

questions.text: Which of the following leukaemias is associated with the given peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear showing an increased number of small, mature lymphocytes with a characteristic smudge appearance is indicative of Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL).

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): (Option A)

 
  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) (Option C)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with Auer rods

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) (Option D)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: Identify the cell in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Mast cell

Explanation:

  • The given image shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue. It contains the acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue.
  • Mast cells are characterized by the presence of large granules & stains with toluidine blue, giving them a distinct purple-blue colour. It plays a crucial role in allergic reactions and inflammation by releasing histamine and other mediators from their granules.

 

Macrophages (Option B) are large phagocytic cells with abundant cytoplasm and a kidney-shaped nucleus. They lack metachromatic granules and do not stain with toluidine blue.

Plasma cells (Option C) have an eccentric nucleus with a clock-face chromatin pattern and a perinuclear hof due to the prominent Golgi apparatus; they produce antibodies but lack granules.

Fibroblasts (Option D) are spindle-shaped cells involved in collagen and extracellular matrix synthesis, lacking granules and immune functions. Histopathologically, they appear as elongated, fusiform cells with a pale, slightly granular cytoplasm and a single, elongated nucleus.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Initially, the lesions started as macules and later developed into nodules. Some of the nodules have a central umbilication. The histology of the lesion is shown below. What would be found on a biopsy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are diagnostic of Molluscum contagiosum lesions, which show intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies/molluscum bodies.

 

Molluscum Contagiosum:

  • Caused by: Poxvirus (MCV-1 to MCV-4)
    • MCV-1 is the most common.
    • MCV-2 is often sexually transmitted.
  • Common in:
    • Children (2-12 years): Spread through direct contact or shared items (e.g., towels)
    • Adults: Typically sexually transmitted, affecting genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs
  • Incubation period: Approximately 6 weeks
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pearly, dome-shaped papules (1-5 mm in diameter) with a dimpled centre.
    • The central waxy core contains cytoplasmic viral inclusions.
  • Common sites in children: Trunk, arms, and legs
  • Common sites in adults: Genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs
  • Microscopic examination:
    • Lesion characteristics: Cup-like, verrucous epidermal hyperplasia.
    • Diagnostic structure: Molluscum body: Large (up to 35 µm), ellipsoid, homogeneous cytoplasmic inclusion.
    • Found in the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
    • Eosinophilic in the stratum granulosum.
    • Pale blue hue in the stratum corneum.

Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells) (Option A) are typically seen in herpesvirus infections (like herpes simplex or varicella-zoster), not in molluscum contagiosum. They are large cells with multiple nuclei, and their presence is a hallmark of herpesvirus infections.

Donovan bodies (Option B) are characteristic of granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. The bodies are intracellular and appear in macrophages. They are unrelated to molluscum contagiosum.

Koilocytes (Option D) are cells with a characteristic perinuclear halo and are associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infections, such as warts.

questions.text: Which of the following needles is commonly used for bone marrow biopsy?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Klima needle.

Klima & Salah’s needles are reusable bone marrow aspiration & biopsy needles made of stainless steel.

  • Klima needle has a guard that screws along the length of the needle & no side screw.
  • Salah needle has a guard and side screw.


 

Jamshidi needle:

  • Has a tapering end to reduce the crushed artefacts in the sample.

 

Islam needle:

  • Has core securing device (cutting edge is shaped to hold the core of the bone during the procedure)

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with a neck swelling that shifts during swallowing. Ultrasound reveals a 2 cm x 2 cm mass in the left lobe of the thyroid, reaching the strap muscles. Histopathology shows findings as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with neck swelling that shifts during swallowing, along with the ultrasound findings of a mass in the thyroid reaching the strap muscles, raises suspicion for a thyroid pathology. The histopathology showing papillae lined with overlapping nuclei and the characteristic "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei is highly indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid:

  • This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterized by lymphatic spread.
  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion
  • HPE shows:
  1. True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core.
  2. Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
  3. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
  4. Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
  5. Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications

 

  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.

 

Medullary Carcinoma of the Thyroid (Option A) arises from the parafollicular C cells, which produce calcitonin. The provided histopathology does not show the typical features of medullary carcinoma, such as nests or clusters of polygonal cells with amyloid deposits.

 

Follicular Carcinoma of the Thyroid (Option B) arises from the thyroid follicular cells. The histopathology image does not display the characteristic features of follicular carcinomas, such as invasion of the tumour capsule or blood vessels.

 

Thyroglossal Cyst (Option C) is a congenital anomaly resulting from the persistence of thyroglossal duct remnants. It typically presents as a midline neck swelling that moves during swallowing. However, the histopathology does not show features typical of a thyroglossal cyst, such as a cystic structure lined by stratified squamous or columnar epithelium.

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) AB

Explanation:

In the given scenario where the blood group is unknown, fresh frozen plasma from blood group AB can be safely administered to the patient.

 

Blood group AB individuals are considered universal plasma donors because their plasma lacks both A and B antibodies, making it compatible with recipients of any ABO blood type without causing an ABO incompatibility reaction.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes?


	KIT has decreased expression via the tyrosine kinase signalling pathway in GIST.
	KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung cancer.
	ERBB2 is overexpressed in association with breast carcinomas.
	PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancer.
questions.solution:
• ERBB2, also known as HER2/neu, is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Amplification or overexpression of the ERBB2 gene occurs in approximately 20-30% of breast carcinomas, resulting in elevated levels of the ERBB2 protein.
  • Overexpression of ERBB2 is linked to more aggressive tumour behaviour and is a target for specific treatments, such as trastuzumab.

 

Proto-oncogene for growth factor receptor

Associated tumour

ERBB (EGFR)

ERBB2 (HER2)

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Amplification Breast carcinoma

FLT3
  • Leukaemia

RET
  • Familial medullary thyroid carcinomas
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A and B,

ALK
  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Certain lymphomas

KIT
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors, Seminomas
  • Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML)
  • Mastocytosis
  • Melanoma

PDGFR-B
  • Brain tumours

 

KRAS mutations (Statement 2) are more commonly associated with non-small cell lung cancer, particularly adenocarcinomas, rather than small-cell lung cancer.

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST) (Statement 1) are associated with activating mutations in the KIT gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. These mutations result in increased expression and constitutive activation of KIT, playing a key role in the development of GIST.

 

PDGFR-β (Statement 4) is not suppressed in colorectal cancer. In fact, overexpression or activation of PDGFR-β has been observed in colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
Which of the following set of statements is true about familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?


	It is autosomal recessive.
	If not treated, 100% of the cases progress to adenocarcinoma of the colon.
	Polyps do not arise after puberty.
	It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: (FAP)

  • An autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5 (Statement 1)
  • Numerous intestinal polyps develop.
  • Classic FAP:
    • Diagnosed with at least 100 polyps.
    • There is almost 100% risk of colorectal cancer if untreated (Statement 2)
    • Commonly develops in 30 years, almost always by 50 years (Statement 3)
  • Attenuated FAP (AFAP):
    • Primarily affects the proximal colon
    • Fewer polyps (average <30 polyps)
    • Associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (Statement 4)
  • Standard treatment: Prophylactic colectomy to prevent colorectal cancer.
  • Post-colectomy risks: Cancer at extracolonic sites, including the ampulla of Vater and stomach

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with fatigue. Investigations reveal the following:


	Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
	MCV: 80 fL
	MCH: 29 pg
	Serum ferritin: 185 μg/L
	TLC: Elevated with predominant lymphocytes and neutrophils.


What is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has normocytic, normochromic anaemia with normal MCV (80 fL) and MCH (29 pg).
  • Elevated serum ferritin (185 μg/L) suggests adequate iron stores, ruling out iron deficiency anaemia.
  • The elevated TLC with predominant lymphocytes and neutrophils indicates an underlying chronic inflammatory or infectious condition consistent with anaemia of chronic disease (ACD).

Low

Thalassemia (Option A) typically presents with microcytic anaemia and reduced MCV, which is not seen here.

 

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option C) typically presents with low ferritin levels, which is not consistent with the patient's ferritin level.

 

Sickle cell anaemia (Option D) usually results in normocytic anaemia but would typically show sickle-shaped cells on a peripheral blood smear, which is not described in this case.

questions.text: Cyclooxygenase plays a role in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase (COX) is an enzyme that plays a key role in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway. It converts arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are involved in inflammation, pain, and fever.


 

Arachidonic Acid Metabolites:

  • Arachidonic acid (AA) is a 20-carbon polyunsaturated fatty acid (5,8,11,14-eicosatetraenoic acid). It is stored in membrane phospholipids and released through the action of phospholipase A2.
  • AA is then converted into lipid mediators, known as eicosanoids, through the action of cyclooxygenases and lipoxygenases.

Prostaglandins (PGs):

  • Produced by Mast cells, macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types.
  • Involved in Vascular and systemic reactions of inflammation.
  • Enzymes: Prostaglandins are synthesized via cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2). COX-1 is constitutively expressed and performs homeostatic functions, while COX-2 is induced in response to inflammation.
  • Key Prostaglandins:
    • PGI2 (prostacyclin) is produced by the vascular endothelium and acts as a vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation.
    • TXA2 is produced by platelets and causes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
    • PGD2 and PGE2 cause vasodilation and increase the permeability of postcapillary venules, promoting oedema formation.
    • PGE2 also contributes to pain and fever during inflammation.

 

Leukotrienes:

  • Produced by: Leukocytes and mast cells through the action of lipoxygenase enzymes, particularly 5-lipoxygenase.
  • Involved in vascular reactions, smooth muscle contraction, and leukocyte recruitment.
  • Key Leukotrienes:
    • LTB4 is a potent chemotactic agent that activates neutrophils and promotes adhesion, generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), and releases lysosomal enzymes.
    • Cysteinyl leukotrienes (LTC4, LTD4, LTE4) cause vasoconstriction, bronchospasm (important in asthma), and increase vascular permeability.

Lipoxins:

  • Produced by: Lipoxins are synthesized via the lipoxygenase pathway, involving both neutrophils and platelets for transcellular biosynthesis.
  • Function: Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to the endothelium, thus limiting the inflammatory response.

 

Kreb’s cycle (Option A) is part of cellular respiration and involves the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins to generate energy. Cyclooxygenase is not involved in this cycle.

 

Leukotriene (Option C) is another class of eicosanoids derived from arachidonic acid, but it is produced via the 5-lipoxygenase pathway, not the cyclooxygenase pathway.

 

Vitamin K (Option D) is involved in the coagulation cascade and is not related to the action of cyclooxygenase.

questions.text:
In a country like India, which is characterized by its varied cultures and languages, what measures should a physician adopt to effectively communicate with patients and ensure improved treatment results?

 

1. Insist on good communication

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions

4. The physician should consider the patient’s religion and cultural perception
questions.solution:
Insist on good communication: Effective communication is vital for ensuring proper diagnosis, treatment, and patient satisfaction. A physician should prioritize clear, open, and empathetic communication, which is especially important in a diverse cultural and linguistic setting like India.

The physician should consider the patient’s religion and cultural perception: Understanding and respecting a patient’s cultural and religious background is essential in providing holistic care. This consideration helps in building trust and in making informed decisions that align with the patient's values and beliefs, which can lead to better treatment outcomes.

1, 2 (Option A): While insisting on good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be the most effective approach, especially when interpreters are not available or when direct communication is possible in a shared language. It is better to attempt direct communication or use an interpreter when necessary rather than relying exclusively on one method.

2, 3 (Option B): Insisting on communication via an interpreter and treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions may not be ideal. Ignoring cultural perceptions can lead to misunderstandings and hinder the development of a good patient-physician relationship, which can negatively impact treatment outcomes.

3, 4 (Option C): Treating patients regardless of cultural perceptions contradicts the idea of respecting the patient’s religion and cultural perceptions, which are crucial for effective care. Ignoring cultural perceptions can lead to suboptimal treatment and may even harm the patient’s trust in the healthcare system.

questions.text:
Match the following stages with their relevant descriptions:

 


	
		
			
			1. Pre-pathogenesis
			
			
			a. Normal course without any intervention
			
		
		
			
			2. Pathogenesis
			
			
			b. Appearance of clinical signs and symptoms
			
		
		
			
			3. Natural history of a disease
			
			
			c. Reaching normalcy with the help of the community
			
		
		
			
			4. Rehabilitation
			
			
			d. Period before the onset of the disease
questions.solution:
Pre-pathogenesis (1-d): This is the period before the onset of the disease, where there are no signs or symptoms of the disease. It's the stage before any pathogenic agents have affected the individual.

 

Pathogenesis (2-b): This stage involves the development of the disease after exposure to the causative agent, and it is marked by the appearance of clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Natural history of a disease (3-a): This refers to the normal course of the disease without any intervention, from its initial exposure to its potential resolution or progression.

 

Rehabilitation (4-c): Rehabilitation refers to the process of reaching normalcy or improving function with the help of the community or medical interventions after the disease has caused some impact.

questions.text: As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are managed with the following treatment approach:

choices.text: 2 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets OD
IV iron sucrose for noncompliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.solution:
As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are generally managed with oral iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets. The typical treatment involves 2 IFA tablets OD (once a day).

  • IV iron sucrose is usually considered for noncompliant patients who are unable to take oral supplements effectively or when oral supplementation does not improve the condition, but it is not the first-line treatment in cases of mild to moderate anemia.
  • IM ferric carboxy maltose (FCM) is also an alternative but is typically reserved for more severe cases of anemia or in cases where intravenous iron is needed.

Therefore, for mild to moderate anemia in pregnant women less than 34 weeks, oral IFA tablets are the standard first-line treatment.

The 6x6x6 strategy is related to anemia mukt Bharat. It stands for 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms.

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose)
  • Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid)
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets)Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.

questions.text:
5-year old Ram and 3-year-old Sham are Rama Devi’s sons. Sham developed a rash, but Rama Devi ignored it, assuming it to be an allergy. After 10 days, Ram also developed a rash along with a fever. Out of fear, Rama Devi took Ram to the primary health center (PHC). The healthcare workers at the PHC suspected it to be measles. Choose all correct options from among the following:

1. Ram is an index case.

2. Sham is a primary case

3. Ram got the infection from Sham

4. Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis if his mother had brought him to the hospital when Sham got the rash.
questions.solution:
In the context of the scenario involving Ram and Sham, the correct options regarding their cases are:

Ram is an index case – This is correct because Ram is the first person in the scenario who prompted healthcare intervention.

Sham is a primary case – This is correct because Sham developed symptoms first, indicating he was likely the initial case.

Ram got the infection from Sham – This is likely correct, as Sham showed symptoms first, and Ram developed symptoms later, suggesting transmission from Sham.

Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis if his mother had brought him to the hospital when Sham got the rash – This is correct because timely intervention could have allowed for post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent measles.

questions.text: The drug shown in the image below is administered for:
questions.solution:
The combination of Artesunate, Sulfadoxine, and Pyrimethamine is used for the treatment of malaria.

  • Artesunate is an effective antimalarial drug that belongs to the class of artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs).
  • Sulfadoxine and Pyrimethamine are used together as a combination therapy for treating uncomplicated malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: According to the guidelines of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), what would be the criteria to designate a district as a high priority district based on the prevalence of HIV TB?
questions.solution: According to the guidelines of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), a district is designated as a high-priority district based on the prevalence of HIV among tuberculosis (TB) patients. Specifically, if more than 10% of TB patients are found to be HIV-positive, the district is categorized as a high-priority area for intensified TB-HIV collaborative activities.

questions.text:
A child presents with a dog bite from a street dog. On examination, an abrasion of 1.5 cm is present, with slight oozing. Which of the following statements is correct?

1. Category 3 wound

2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes

3. Clean the wound with spirit

4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing

5. Equine immunoglobulin is given a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice

6. The intradermal vaccine is administered on day 0,3,7,28
questions.solution:
1. Category 3 wound (1):
    • The wound involves an abrasion with oozing, which qualifies as a Category 3 exposure as per WHO guidelines. This category includes single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membranes with saliva, and exposure to broken skin.
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2):
    • Immediate and thorough washing of the wound with soap and water for 15–20 minutes is a key step in rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). It significantly reduces the viral load at the site.
  3. Clean the wound with spirit (3):
    • This is correct. After washing and drying the wound, disinfectants like povidone-iodine and spirit can be applied.
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4):
    • Suturing is avoided in rabies-prone wounds unless absolutely necessary. If required, it is done only after administering rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound.
  5. Equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice (5):
    • ERIG is administered in Category 3 wounds at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight. It is infiltrated locally around the wound as much as anatomically possible, with the remaining dose given intramuscularly, only once.
  6. Intradermal vaccine schedule: Days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6):
    • The child should receive the intradermal rabies vaccine on this schedule as part of PEP for a Category 3 wound.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

  • Option A (2, 3, 5, 6): Cleaning the wound with spirit (3) is incorrect.
  • Option C (1, 2, 3, 5): Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and the vaccine schedule is missing (6).
  • Option D (1, 2, 3, 6): Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and RIG (5) is omitted.

questions.text: Identify the formula given below:
questions.solution:
Standard deviation is considered the most comprehensive and widely used measure of dispersion in statistical analysis.

 

Measures of dispersion

Definition

Calculation

Standard deviation

Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean.

σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n)

Range

The difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

Range = Maximum value - Minimum value

Mean deviation

Measures the average absolute deviation of data points from the mean.

Mean deviation = ∑ X - x̄ / n

Variance

Measures the average of the squared differences from the mean.

Variance = σ2

questions.text: Which methods are used to evaluate contraceptive failure?
questions.solution:
The Pearl Index is calculated as the number of pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure to a contraceptive method. It is a technique for evaluating contraceptive efficacy.

 

Formula

(Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure) x 1200

Numerator

The total number of accidental pregnancies, including pregnancies that resulted in live births, stillbirths, abortions, or are ongoing.

Denominator

(Total months in the review period) – (months stopped using contraception for non-pregnancy reasons)

Minimum Data

At least 600 months of exposure.

Disadvantages
  • PI assumes a constant failure rate over time, but contraceptive failure rates typically decline with longer use.
  • High-fertility couples conceive earlier, skewing results towards lower-fertility couples later in studies.
  • PI ignores factors beyond accidental pregnancy that affect effectiveness, like user dissatisfaction, side effects, attempts to conceive, or loss of follow-up.

Better methods

Life Table Analysis is a better method to evaluate contraceptive efficacy.

It calculates cumulative failure rates over a specified time frame, like one

month.


 

Pharmacological index (Option A): There is no such index specifically used to evaluate contraceptive failure.

 

Performance index (Option C): This refers to an evaluation of overall performance, often in industrial or technical contexts, and is not used for contraceptive failure assessment.

 

Efficacy index (Option D): Although the term "efficacy" can relate to the effectiveness of contraceptives, there is no specific "efficacy index" used for evaluating contraceptive failure.

 

Reference:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding drugs used in anti-tubercular treatment are true?

A. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis

B. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer

C. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis

D. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
A. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis: True. Isoniazid (INH) is a bactericidal drug that specifically inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid, a key component of the mycobacterial cell wall. This mechanism is critical for its effectiveness against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

D. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase: True. Bedaquiline is a newer anti-tubercular drug that specifically targets mycobacterial ATP synthase, disrupting energy production in the bacteria. It is used for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

B. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer: False. Pyrazinamide is not an enzyme inducer. It works by disrupting mycobacterial membrane function and energy production. Rifampicin, not pyrazinamide, is a strong enzyme inducer.

 

C. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis: False. Rifampicin is used for other conditions besides tuberculosis, including leprosy, meningococcal prophylaxis, and certain staphylococcal infections. It is not exclusive to tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: Under which category of disaster management does the modification of building codes to construct earthquake-resistant buildings fall?
questions.solution:
Modifying building codes to construct earthquake-resistant buildings is a preventive measure taken to reduce the impact of potential disasters. Disaster mitigation involves steps to minimize risks and vulnerabilities, such as structural improvements and planning.

 

Disaster response (Option A): This refers to actions taken immediately after a disaster occurs, such as search and rescue, providing medical aid, and emergency relief. Modifying building codes does not fall under this category.

 

Disaster reconstruction (Option B): This involves rebuilding and restoring infrastructure and communities after a disaster has occurred. Building earthquake-resistant structures during reconstruction could be part of this phase but does not pertain to modifying codes as a proactive measure.

 

Disaster rehabilitation (Option C): Rehabilitation focuses on restoring normalcy and providing long-term support to affected individuals and communities, such as psychological care and restoring livelihoods. It does not include modifying building codes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with knee pain. The x-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Osteoclastoma. Osteoclastoma, also known as a giant cell tumor, is a locally aggressive and destructive bone tumor that is composed of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells.

  • Osteoclastoma is most commonly seen in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones such as the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.

 

  • Soap bubble appearance is the characteristic radiological finding of giant cell tumors.
  • It presents as a lytic lesion with multiple internal septations, giving it a soap bubble appearance. It is usually located in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur.

 

X-ray findings in Giant cell tumors (GCTs):

  • Eccentric location, often subchondral.
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
  • The cortex may be thinned out.

Lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition produce a soap bubble appearance.

  • No calcification within the tumor.
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.
  • The tumor usually does not enter the adjacent joint.

 

Treatment:

  • The treatment of choice is excision.
  • Followed by reconstruction procedures and bone grafting or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) insertion.
  • Adjuvant treatments:
    • Liquid nitrogen and phenol have been shown to decrease recurrences.
    • Bisphosphonates like zoledronate or pamidronate
  • Radiotherapy- especially for spine GCTs
  • Drugs:

Denosumab- anti-RANKL monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: What is the most frequent pattern of involvement observed in Pott’s spine?
questions.solution:
Pott's spine, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, affects the spine, leading to granulomatous lesions.

  • Paradiscal involvement, the most common pattern, begins at the intervertebral disc, spreading to adjacent vertebrae, potentially causing neurological deficits.
  • Thoraco-lumbar region (D12, L1) is mostly affected, typically in the first three decades of life.
  • Manifestations include bone destruction, cold abscess, and Pott's paraplegia.
  • Spinal TB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB via hematogenous spread.
  • Hematogenous spread occurs through arterial or venous routes, facilitated by subchondral arterial arcade and Batson's venous plexus.
  • Clinical manifestations include a stiff, painful back, rare systemic symptoms, and classical night cries.
  • Deformities include loss of lordosis, followed by gibbus formation, primarily in the thoracic spine.
  • Paraplegia tends to be spastic, especially in the thoracic spine.
  • Imaging modalities include X-ray (loss of plate margins, radiolucency), CT scan (preferred for degeneration assessment), and MRI (best for early diagnosis)

questions.text: Amongst the following, which is the most suitable combination of foot deformities typical to CTEV?
questions.solution:
Correct answer  (B)Equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, cavus.

This combination of foot deformities is typical of CTEV.

  • Equinus refers to a condition where the foot is in a plantarflexed position, pointing downward.
  • Inversion refers to a position where the foot points inward.
  • Forefoot adduction refers to a position where the forefoot turns inward.
  • Cavus refers to high arch in foot.

 

Congenital Talipes EquinoVarus (CTEV) or club foot

  • Most common congenital malformations characterised by varying degrees and severity of predictable contractures.

 

Four components:

  • Midfoot cavus
  • Forefoot adductus
  • Heel/Hindfoot varus
  • Hindfoot equinus

 

Etiology:

  • Maternal smoking and maternal diabetes have strong association.
  • Maternal alcohol consumption.
  • Strongly associated with congenital myotonic dystrophy, myelomeningocele, distal arthrogryposis, trisomy 18 and chromosome 22q11 deletion syndrome.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • The deformity predominantly exists in the tarsal bones which are in the position of maximum flexion and adduction.
  • The talus is characteristically medially deviated while the calcaneus is in varus and rotated medially around the talus.
  • The navicular and cuboid are displaced medially.

 

Clubfoot can be associated with:

  • Arthrogryposis
  • Myelomeningocele
  • Amniotic band syndrome
  • Spina bifida

 

Radiography is the most important investigation

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) T4N1MO

 

Explanation:

  • The TNM staging of this patient with laryngeal carcinoma is T4N1M0 since there is an invasion of the tumor into the cricoid and thyroid cartilage, and there is an extension of the tumor into adjacent soft tissues of the neck, which includes the strap muscles, thyroid, and deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue.
  • There is single, ipsilateral lymph node involvement measuring less than 3cm in size with no distant metastasis.

 

Subglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis. (Option A ruled out)

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. (Option D ruled out)

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). (Option B)

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Regional lymph nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

 

Distant metastasis

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:

1. Cochlear nucleus

2. Spiral ganglion

3. Superior olivary nucleus

4. Inferior colliculus

5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

Explanation:

  • 2-Spiral ganglion: The auditory pathway starts with the spiral ganglion (which contains cell bodies of auditory nerve fibers). In response to sound, the cochlear hair cells generate impulses that are transmitted along these auditory fibers.
  • 1-Cochlear nucleus: These fibers enter the brainstem and synapse with the cochlear nucleus.
  • 3-Superior olivary nucleus: Some fibers cross to the opposite side and enter the superior olivary complex.
  • 4-Inferior colliculus: The fibers ascend and enter the inferior colliculus (midbrain).
  • 5- Medial geniculate body: Signals are relayed to the medial geniculate body (thalamus). Fibers then relay to the auditory cortex (Brodmann's area 41) (superior temporal gyrus).

 

Auditory pathway:

  1. Cochlea
  2. Cochlear Nerve
  3. Cochlear Nucleus (in the brainstem)
  4. Superior Olivary Complex
  5. Lateral Lemniscus
  6. Inferior Colliculus (in the midbrain)
  7. Medial Geniculate Nucleus (in the thalamus)
  8. Primary Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals are sent to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (Heschl’s gyrus), where sound perception, including the identification of pitch, rhythm and speech occurs.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a history of cough, on-and-off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with granulations in the nose. His chest X-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and necrosis. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Wegener's granulomatosis

 

Explanation:

The combination of upper respiratory tract involvement (saddle nose, septal perforation), lower respiratory tract involvement (cough, hemoptysis, cavitary lesions), and the biopsy findings (granulomas, multinucleated giant cells, and necrosis) strongly points towards Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis).

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:

  • Previously known as Wegener’s granulomatosis.
  • It is a systemic granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels.
  • More common in Caucasians (90%).

 

Clinical features:

  • Upper respiratory tract symptoms:
    • Clear or purulent bloody nasal discharge
    • Sinusitis
    • On examination, crusting, granulations, septal perforation, and a saddle nose.
  • Lower respiratory tract symptoms: cough, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis.
  • kidneys: Hematuria, later renal failure.
  • Oral: ‘strawberry’ gingival hyperplasia is said to be pathognomonic.
  • Skin: ulceration and nodules.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Chest X-ray: Nodules, fixed infiltrates or cavities
  • Urine analysis: Microscopic haematuria with or without red cell casts.
  • Biopsy: Necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma, and necrotizing vasculitis involving small arteries or veins.
  • c-ANCA (cytoplasmic ANCA): Positive in 90% of the cases.
  • p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA): Positive in 10% of the cases.
  • CT and MRI: Non-specific mucosal thickening in the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses, bone destruction, and new bone formation in the walls of the sinus cavities.

 

Treatment:

  • Systemic corticosteroids.
  • Cyclophosphamide, azathioprine, methotrexate and rituximab are used.

 

Tuberculosis (Option B): While TB can cause granulomas, the combination of nasal destruction (septal perforation, saddle nose) with lung cavities is more characteristic of GPA. TB can present with hemoptysis, but it's less commonly associated with the rapid destruction of nasal cartilage leading to saddle nose deformity as seen in GPA.

 

Syphilis (Option C): Congenital syphilis can cause a saddle nose deformity. However, the other symptoms described (cough, hemoptysis, cavitary lung lesions, and the specific biopsy findings) are not typical of syphilis. Also, lung involvement is not a common presentation of syphilis.

 

Sarcoidosis (Option D): Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can affect the lungs and upper respiratory tract. While it can cause granulomas on biopsy and lung involvement, it's less likely to cause destructive nasal changes like saddle nose deformity and septal perforation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. She has a history of FESS following failed conservative management 5 years ago. Post-surgical notes mentioned that uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation were done during the previous FESS. DNE currently shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of recurrent or persistent rhinosinusitis despite previous functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). The key finding is mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining with patent ostia. This suggests inflammation as the primary issue, not anatomical obstruction.
  • Since the ostia are patent, drainage is not the problem, making further surgery less likely to be beneficial at this stage. Hence, it requires antihistamines and steroid irrigation.
  • Steroid irrigation reduces mucosal edema and antihistamines help in controlling allergic symptoms and mucosal edema.

Non-Allergic Rhinitis: Treatment

  • Non-allergic rhinitis presents with symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis (nasal obstruction, rhinorrhoea, sneezing) but without positive allergy tests.
  • Treatment is categorised into medical and surgical options.

Medical Treatment:

 

Treatment Type

Details

Lifestyle Modifications

Avoid triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, air blasts, and dust. Practical changes to minimise symptom triggers

Pharmacological Management
  • Antihistamines and Decongestants: Alleviate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and rhinorrhoea.
  • Topical Steroid Sprays: Control Symptoms. Eg. Beclomethasone dipropionate, budesonide, fluticasone
  • Systemic Steroids: Used for severe cases for a short time
  • Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray: Effective for Excessive Rhinorrhoea.

Psychological Support

Address emotional factors; consider counselling and tranquillisers.

 

Repeat surgery (Option A): Repeat surgery is not indicated in this scenario as it could be initially conservatively managed with steroid irrigation and antihistamines. Later, if the symptoms persist, surgical management can be considered.

 

Macrolides for 4 months (Option B): It is prescribed in case of chronic rhinosinusitis.

 

Biological therapy (Option D): Biological therapy is indicated only in severe refractory cases which show symptoms of active inflammation

questions.text: Which is not used for testing olfaction?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Arnold stick test

 

Explanation:

  • Arnold stick test, also known as Arnold cough reflex is an involuntary cough reflex due to the stimulation of the external ear. It is mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve).
  • Insertion of a cotton bud or touching the external ear activates the nerve and evokes a forceful cough. Hence, the name 'Arnold stick'. It is not used to assess olfaction.

 

UPSIT Test is University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test: (Option C ruled out)

  • It is a subjective test to assess smell perception.
  • Patients are given scratch cards of odorous stimuli to identify.
  • It is used to diagnose olfactory dysfunction associated with certain diseases.

 

Tests done to assess nasal airflow:

  • Subjective Tests:
    • Nasal Airflow Questionnaire
    • Visual Analog Scale (VAS)
  • Objective Tests:
    • Rhinomanometry
    • Acoustic Rhinometry
    • Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF)

 

Tests done for smell perception:

  • University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
  • Sniffin' Sticks Test
  • CC-SIT (Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test) (Option D ruled out)
  • Smell diskettes (Option A ruled out)
  • Odor Threshold Test
  • Olfactory Event-Related Potentials (OERP)

questions.text: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image according to the Sade classification?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Grade 2

 

Explanation:

The given image is a grade 2 tympanic membrane retraction. The tympanic membrane gets retracted deep enough to come in contact with the incus and stapes.

  • Grade 1: Slight retraction of the pars tensa.
  • Grade 2: Retraction onto the incus. (Option B)
  • Grade 3: Retraction onto the promontory, but not adherent.
  • Grade 4: Adhesion onto the promontory.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented to the psychiatry outpatient department (OPD) exhibiting symptoms of hypomania. She has a previous history of a manic episode. Currently, she is considering pregnancy. Which medication should be avoided due to its high teratogenic potential for the developing fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Valproate

 

Explanation:

  • Valproate (valproic acid) is known to have a high teratogenic potential and should be avoided in women who are planning pregnancy.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (such as spina bifida) and other congenital malformations if used during pregnancy.
  • Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing medication primarily used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, which is highly teratogenic and is contraindicated in pregnancy and in women of childbearing age.

 

Lithium (Option B) is also associated with some risks, particularly cardiac malformations (like Ebstein's anomaly, about 1 in 1000, a rare congenital heart defect). However, the risk of teratogenicity is lower compared to valproate.

Oxcarbazepine (Option C) is an anticonvulsant medication that is sometimes used to treat bipolar disorder. It is not known to be highly teratogenic, but there is limited data on its safety during pregnancy. It is generally considered to be safer than valproate and lithium.

Olanzapine (Option D) is an atypical antipsychotic that is generally considered to have a lower teratogenic risk compared to mood stabilizers like valproate.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After 5 months of treatment, he developed hyperpigmentation in the palms and soles. What is likely the drug causing it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Emtricitabine

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely drug causing hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas in a patient who is on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART) is Emtricitabine.
  • Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is commonly used in the treatment of HIV.
  • It has been associated with the development of hyperpigmentation in some patients.
  • The hyperpigmentation is usually seen on the palms and soles and may be accompanied by nail discoloration.
  • This side effect is thought to be due to the drug's effects on melanin synthesis.
