questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for hyperlipidemia develops gallstones. What is the mechanism of action of the causative drug that was given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Activates PPAR alpha

 

Explanation:

  • The causative drug here is likely a fibrate, which is commonly used to treat hyperlipidemia.
  • Fibrates, such as fenofibrate and gemfibrozil, activate PPAR-alpha (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha), a transcription factor involved in regulating lipid and glucose metabolism.
  • PPAR activation leads to increased expression of enzymes involved in fatty acid oxidation and decreased expression of enzymes involved in triglyceride synthesis and VLDL secretion.
  • All fibrates increase bile lithogenicity, and increase the incidence of gallstones.

Inhibits HMG CoA reductase (Option A): Statins work by inhibiting HMG CoA reductase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis. Major side effects are myopathy and derangement of LFTs. They do not typically cause gallstones.

 

Blinds to deoxycholic acid (Option C): Deoxycholic acid is a bile acid that is involved in the emulsification and absorption of dietary fat. Bile acid sequestrants bind to bile acids in the GI contents and prevent their reabsorption. They do not have a high risk of gallstones associated with them.

 

Decrease VLDL (Option D): Decreases VLDL is the mechanism of action of some lipid-lowering drugs, such as niacin and omega-3 fatty acids. While decreasing VLDL can have beneficial effects on lipid metabolism, it does not have a similar risk of gallstones formation as fibrates.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cetuximab

 

Explanation:

  • Cetuximab is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It is a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in cancer cells, thus preventing cell proliferation.
  • It treats certain types of colorectal and head and neck cancers that overexpress EGFR rather than HER2.
  • Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab & Atezolimumab are all immune checkpoint inhibitors. (Other options ruled out)

 

Immune checkpoint inhibitors:

  • They are a class of cancer immunotherapy drugs that target the PD-1 receptor on T-cells.

questions.solution:

Explanation:

  • We can see that Drug 1 produces a higher response than Drug 4 at all concentrations and above the baseline.

 

Type of agonists

Characteristics

Full agonist (Drug 1)

It activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to the physiological signal molecule

Partial agonist (Drug 2)

It activates a receptor to produce a submaximal effect and can block the action of a full agonist.

Inverse agonist (Drug 4)

It activates a receptor to produce an effect opposite to that of an agonist

Neutral antagonist (Drug 3)

Competitive antagonist

Non-competitive antagonist

questions.text:
A patient presented with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and was found to have pancreatic necrosis. Which of the following are included in the management of the condition?


	Antibiotics IV
	IV fluids
	Culture
	MRI
	Assisted drainage
	Laparotomy
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 2, 3 and 5 are included in the management of Pancreatic Necrosis.

  • It refers to a diffuse or focal area of non-viable parenchyma.
  • Pathogenesis: It involves peripancreatic fat lysis, leading to an acute necrotic collection (ANC) with fluid and necrotic material, developing a defined inflammatory capsule, and evolving into walled-off necrosis (WON).
  • Types: Sterile (initial stage) and Infected.
  • CECT scan: An absence of parenchymal enhancement.
  • Culture and Sensitivity: Aspirated fluid is sent for culture and sensitivity. (Statement 3)
  • Management:
    • Supportive measures (IV fluids and stabilisation) (Statement 2)
    • Sterile necrotic material should not be drained or interfered with.
    • Signs of sepsis (purulent aspirate):
      • Drainage (endoscopic ultrasound-guided is preferred) of the infected fluid. (Statement 5)
      • Antibiotic therapy (Statement 1)
      • Pancreatic necrosectomy (laparotomy). (Statement 6)

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (Statement 4) is not typically used in the management of pancreatic necrosis. It may be used later in the course of the disease to assess the extent of necrosis or complications. CT scan is preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a potential complication in a 40-year-old man who presents with a 15-day history of fever and a 1-day history of altered sensorium and is diagnosed with Plasmodium falciparum through a rapid diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Arterial pH >7.2 (alkalosis) is not a complication associated with Plasmodium falciparum infection. Severe malaria caused by P. falciparum can trigger metabolic acidosis in which the arterial pH is less than 7.2.

 

Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <40 mg/dL) (Option A) can be a complication of severe malaria, particularly in cases of P. falciparum infection. The parasite's impact on the liver and the increased metabolic demands of the infection can lead to low blood sugar levels.

 

The presence of serum creatinine levels of -5.2 (Option C), indicating a significant decrease in renal clearance, suggests acute kidney injury (AKI). Malaria-associated AKI can result from various factors, such as decreased blood flow to the kidneys, direct parasite-mediated damage, or immune-mediated injury.

 

Cerebral malaria, characterized by impaired consciousness and unarousable coma (Option D) is a severe complication that can occur in P. falciparum infection.

 

Complications of Malaria:

 

  • Cerebral malaria, Convulsions
  • Black water fever
  • Jaundice
  • Septicemic malaria: The presence of malaria parasites in the bloodstream, leading to systemic inflammation, septic shock, and multiple organ dysfunction.
  • Algid malaria: causes peripheral circulatory failure
  • Noncardiogenic Pulmonary Edema and ARDS
  • Renal failure/Acute kidney injury (AKI)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Severe anemia
  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Metabolic acidosis and shock
  • Bleeding disturbances
  • Hyperreactive malarial Splenomegaly
  • Quartan malarial nephropathy
  • EBV infection, Burkitt's lymphoma

questions.text: Dorzolamide is a ………….?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Explanation:

  • Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, an ophthalmic medication, that is used topically (in eye drops) to treat conditions like glaucoma and ocular hypertension.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors block the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which is involved in the production of aqueous humor in the eye.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, dorzolamide reduces the amount of fluid produced, thus helping to lower intraocular pressure and preventing damage to the optic nerve in conditions like glaucoma.

 

 

Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial (Option A): Although dorzolamide is a sulfonamide, it is not used as an antibacterial agent but as a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor for the eye.

 

Second–generation sulfonylurea (Option C) refers to a class of oral medications used to treat type 2 diabetes, which is unrelated to dorzolamide.

 

Opioid receptor agonist (Option D): Dorzolamide does not affect opioid receptors, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paracetamol

 

Explanation:

  • NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) is a toxic metabolite that is formed when paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen) is metabolized by the liver.
  • Under normal circumstances, paracetamol is metabolized into non-toxic compounds that are excreted in the urine.
  • However, when the dose of paracetamol exceeds a certain threshold, the liver's metabolic pathways become overwhelmed, and NAPQI accumulates in the liver, where it can cause hepatotoxicity.
  • Acetaminophen nomogram is used to interpret serum acetaminophen concentrations in relation to time since ingestion in order to assess potential hepatotoxicity.
  • Paracetamol overdose → Increased production of toxic metabolite NAPQI (catalysed by CYP2E1) → Depletes glutathione (which normally neutralises NAPQI) → Leads to NAPQI binding to liver cells, causing Zonal necrosis/ centrilobular necrosis with periportal sparing.

 

Aspirin (Option A), Diclofenac (Option C) ,and Ketorolac (Option D are not metabolized to NAPQI.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition?

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4

 

Explanation:

  • Beta-lactam antibiotics work by inhibiting the action of enzymes involved in cell wall synthesis, weakening the cell wall and making it more susceptible to osmotic pressure.
  • The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. The various steps involved in bacterial cell wall formation are:
    • UDP-N-acetylglucosamine (UDP-NAG) and UDP-N-acetylmuramic acid (UDP-NAM) are synthesized in the cytoplasm of the bacterial cell.
    • UDP-NAM is linked to a lipid carrier molecule called bactoprenol phosphate, which forms lipid II.
    • Lipid II is flipped across the cytoplasmic membrane to the outer surface, where it is incorporated into the growing cell wall.
    • The peptide chains of adjacent lipid II molecules are cross-linked by enzymes called transpeptidases, also known as penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).
  • Based on the above steps, the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics is option 4, which is the site where transpeptidases or PBPs are involved in cross-linking the peptide chains of adjacent lipid II molecules.
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics, such as penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems, work by irreversibly binding to the active site of PBPs, thereby inhibiting their function. This leads to a weakened cell wall and eventual cell death

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G proteins – coupled receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gq

 

Explanation:

  • Phospholipase C (PLC) acts via Gq-coupled receptors.
  • When ligand-bound G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are activated, Gq protein stimulates phospholipase C (PLC).
  • PLC hydrolyses phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) into inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) which act as second messengers.
  • IP3 binds to receptors on the endoplasmic reticulum, releasing calcium ions (Ca2+), which activate calcium-dependent enzymes and protein kinases.
  • DAG remains in the plasma membrane, activating protein kinase C (PKC) to phosphorylate target proteins, initiating cellular responses like gene expression and cell growth

 

G Protein Type

Effector

Second Messenger(s)

Pathway

Gs

(Option A)

Adenylyl cyclase

Cyclic AMP (cAMP)

Increases cAMP, activates protein kinase A (PKA)

Gi

(Option B)

Adenylyl cyclase

Reduces cyclic AMP (cAMP)

Decreases cAMP, inhibits protein kinase A (PKA)

Gq

Phospholipase C (PLC)

Inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and DAG

IP3 releases Ca2+ from ER; DAG activates protein kinase C (PKC)

 

Go (Option D) is involved in the inhibition of voltage-gated calcium channels and the regulation of potassium channels, but it does not activate PLC.

questions.text: Urine alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin

 

Explanation:

  • Urinary alkalinization is a technique used to increase the pH of urine, which can increase the excretion of weakly acidic drugs that are cleared by the kidneys such as aspirin.

Urine alkalinization involves administering bicarbonate (usually sodium bicarbonate) to make the urine more basic.

  • This raises the pH of the urine, causing acidic drugs like aspirin to become more ionized and thus increase renal excretion.

Aspirin Toxicity:

Explanation
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis

Dosage and Toxicity
  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism)
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation
  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management

Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

 

 

Beta-blockers (Option A): The primary treatment for beta-blocker toxicity includes the use of atropine, glucagon, and sometimes calcium to improve heart rate and contractility. Urine alkalinization is not a recommended treatment for beta-blocker poisoning.

 

Calcium channel blockers (Option B): CCB toxicity is typically treated with calcium (IV calcium gluconate or calcium chloride) and other interventions like glucagon and insulin therapy. Urine alkalinization is not effective for this type of toxicity.

 

Acetaminophen (Option C): The treatment for acetaminophen toxicity involves N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which replenishes glutathione and helps in detoxifying the harmful NAPQI metabolite. Urine alkalinization is not used for acetaminophen poisoning.

questions.text:
Match the following Diuretics in column A to their site of action in column B

 


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			
				Acetazolamide
				Torsemide
				Chlorthalidone
				Vasopressin
			
			
			
			
				Thick ascending loop of Henle
				Collecting duct
				Distal convoluted tubule
				Proximal convoluted tubule
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

Explanation:

1. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that works in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron to inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. This results in a mild diuretic effect and the excretion of excess fluids and electrolytes.

2. Torsemide is a loop diuretic that works in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle to inhibit the reabsorption of sodium, potassium, and chloride ions. Torsemide blocks the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter, thus decreasing the amount of ions that are reabsorbed into the bloodstream and increasing the amount of ions that are excreted in the urine.

3. Chlorthalidone: This is a thiazide-like diuretic that works in the distal convoluted tubule to inhibit the reabsorption of sodium ions. By blocking the Na+/Cl- cotransporter, chlorthalidone decreases the amount of sodium that is reabsorbed into the bloodstream and increases the amount of sodium that is excreted in the urine. This results in a moderate diuretic effect.

4. Vasopressin: This is not a diuretic, but rather an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) that works in the collecting duct to increase water reabsorption. Vasopressin acts on the V2 receptor in the collecting duct to stimulate the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical membrane, which allows for the reabsorption of water. This results in a decrease in urine volume and an increase in urine concentration.

questions.text:
Match the following antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanism of action:


	
		
			
			Mechanism of action
			
			
			Drug
			
		
		
			
			
				Na+ channel blocker
				K+ channel blocker
				Na+, K+ ATPase inhibitor
				Beta-blocker
			
			
			
			
				Quinidine
				Digoxin
				Esmolol
				Ibutilde
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

Drug

MOA

Quinidine

Is a Na+ channel blocker, which is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that acts by blocking sodium channels in the cardiac cells. By blocking these channels, it decreases the influx of sodium ions during the depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential.

Digoxin

It is a Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor, which is not primarily considered an antiarrhythmic drug but rather a cardiac glycoside. However, it does have some antiarrhythmic effects. Digoxin inhibits the activity of the Na+ K+ ATPase pump, and increases intracellular calcium levels, leading to increased contractility of the heart. This indirectly helps to control certain arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation

Esmolol

It belongs to the class of beta-blockers, specifically a short-acting selective beta-1 adrenergic receptor blocker. It works by blocking the beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, thereby reducing the effects of sympathetic stimulation.

Ibutilide

It is a potassium channel blocker, which is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks potassium channels in the heart. By inhibiting these channels, it prolongs the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, resulting in an increase in the action potential duration and effective refractory period.

questions.text: In relation to drug absorption, what does the term "extent" signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Area under the curve

 

Explanation:

Area under the curve (AUC) is a quantitative representation of the “extent of drug absorption” i;e. overall amount of drug that enters the bloodstream and is available for action, in a plasma concentration-time curve.

 

Tmax (Option A) is the time at which the maximum concentration (Cmax) of the drug is reached in the bloodstream.

 

Cmax (Option C) is the maximum concentration of the drug in the bloodstream, indicating the peak of the drug's absorption.

 

t1/2 (Option D) is the time it takes for the drug's concentration in the blood to decrease by half.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Raltegravir

 

Explanation:

  • In the given image, step 5 represents the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome. This step is crucial for the virus to establish a persistent infection.
  • Raltegravir belongs to a class of antiviral drugs called integrase inhibitors. It inhibits the integration of viral DNA into the host genome by targeting the viral integrase enzyme. Therefore, raltegravir acts at step 5

 

Integrase inhibitors

MOA
  • Prevent the formation of covalent bonds between host and viral DNA
  • Inhibit the process known as strand transfer, which is a critical step in the integration of viral DNA into the host genome.

Drugs

Ends with the word -gravir: BCDER

  • Bictegravir
  • Cabotegravir
  • Dolutegravir (most used in India and safe during pregnancy)
  • Elvitegravir (used in combination with cobicistat)
  • Raltegravir

Route
  • All oral drugs except Cabotegravir (IM, once every 3 months)

Metabolism
  • CYP3A4 substrates
  • Rifampicin reduces the effect, hence increasing the dose of the integrase inhibitor

Uses
  • Treatment and post-exposure prophylaxis of HIV
  • Dolutegravir and Lamivudine: First line in treatment-naive HIV patients

Side effects
  • Rashes
  • Steven Johnson syndrome: Epidermis of the skin is damaged
  • Raltegravir: Rhabdomyolysis, DRESS
  • Bictegravir: Increase metformin concentration, hepatoxicity
  • Avoid administration with divalent cations (magnesium- or aluminium-containing antacids, iron supplements)

 

Enfuvirtide (Option B) is a fusion inhibitor. It prevents the virus from entering the host cell by blocking the fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane, acting at Step 2 of the viral life cycle.

 

Tenofovir (Option C) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It blocks the reverse transcription of viral RNA into DNA, acting at Step 3 of the viral cycle.

 

Zidovudine (Option D) is also a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It blocks the reverse transcription of viral RNA into DNA, acting at Step 3 of the viral cycle.

questions.text: A patient who is a known addict is brought to the hospital due to intoxication with an unknown substance. An ocular examination shows the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine
It cannot be reversed by levallorphan
It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus
Tolerance develops due to long-term use

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus

Explanation:

  • The question states that the patient was an addict and intoxicated, the image given shows pupil constriction (miosis), which suggests that the patient was intoxicated with opioids.
  • The Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain is part of this system, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation.
  • The Edinger-Westphal pathway is a part of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) pathway, and it plays a central role in the pupillary light reflex and accommodation reflex.

 

  • Opioids such as morphine, fentanyl, and heroin can activate the mu-opioid receptors in the EW nucleus, resulting in the release of acetylcholine (ACh), a neurotransmitter that stimulates the pupillary sphincter muscle.
  • In addition to the EW nucleus, opioids can also activate mu-opioid receptors in other parts of the brainstem, which can further contribute to respiratory depression, sedation, and analgesia.

This action can be reversed by phenylephrine (Option A): Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist that causes mydriasis (pupil dilation) by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system. It can dilate the pupils in certain conditions, but it would not reverse miosis caused by opioid intoxication or other parasympathetic activation.

It cannot be reversed by levallorphan (Option B): Levallorphan is an opioid antagonist similar to naloxone, and it can reverse opioid-induced effects such as miosis. However, it is not commonly used in clinical practice because it has a shorter duration of action than naloxone and can cause withdrawal symptoms in individuals who are physically dependent on opioids.

Tolerance develops due to long-term use (Option D): Tolerance can develop with long-term use of opioids, leading to a decrease in the effectiveness of the medication and an increased risk of overdose. However, tolerance alone does not cause overdose; rather, overdose occurs when someone takes too much of the opioi,d and the body is unable to handle the excess.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female presents with recent episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, she has a systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated anti-streptolysin O titers and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. An echocardiogram reveals moderate regurgitation in the mitral valve. A biopsy of her heart tissue is performed, and a pathology image is provided below.



Which of the following statements about this pathology is not true?

choices.text: Present in myocardium and endocardium only

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Present in myocardium and endocardium only:

  • This patient's presentation, including elevated anti-streptolysin O titers and elevated ESR with heart valve involvement, suggests the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. The mitral and aortic valves are mostly involved, with resultant regurgitations in the acute stages of the disease. 
  • The pathology image shows a microscopic view of cardiac tissue stained with H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin).
  • Within the myocardium, there are characteristic Aschoff bodies, which appear as granulomatous nodules containing central fibrinoid necrosis, foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages.
  • During acute RF, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart, resulting in pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis (pancarditis).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fibrinoid necrosis in the center: Aschoff bodies typically show fibrinoid necrosis in the center.

Option C - Uncommon in chronic stages: Aschoff bodies are rarely seen in patients with chronic RHD because of the long intervals between the initial insult and the development of valve deformity. They are most often seen only in patients with acute RF.

Option D - Anitschkow cells: Aschoff bodies are indeed surrounded by Anitschkow cells, the plump activated macrophages that have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”).
